{{Infobox games | Name = IX ASEAN Para Games | Logo = 2017 ASEAN Para Games logo.png | Size = 250 px | Events = 369 in 16 sports | Optional caption = | host city = [[Kuala Lumpur]], [[Malaysia]] | motto = Rising Together
({{lang-ms|Bangkit Bersama}}) | Nations participating=11 | Athletes participating= 1452 | Opening ceremony = 17 September | Closing ceremony = 23 September | Officially opened by = [[Najib Razak]]
{{small|[[Prime Minister of Malaysia]]}} | Athlete's Oath = Sharifah Raudzah Syed Akil | Judge's Oath = Teo Kian Joo | torch lighter = [[Hasihin Sanawi]] | Stadium =[[Bukit Jalil National Stadium]] | Medals contested = | Website= [http://kualalumpur2017.com.my/ 2017 ASEAN Para Games] | previous = [[2015 ASEAN Para Games|Singapore 2015]] | next = [[2019 ASEAN Para Games|Philippines 2019]] }} The '''2017 [[ASEAN Para Games]]''' ({{lang-ms|Sukan Para ASEAN 2017}}), officially known as the '''9th ASEAN Para Games''' ({{lang-ms|Sukan Para ASEAN ke-9}}), was a [[Southeast Asian]] [[Disabled sports|disabled]] [[multi-sport event]] held in [[Kuala Lumpur]], [[Malaysia]], 17 days after the [[2017 Southeast Asian Games]] from 17 to 23 September 2017. This was the third time Malaysia host the ASEAN Para Games and its first time since [[2009 ASEAN Para Games|2009]].{{cite web|url=http://www.thesundaily.my/node/414518|title=Chess included in list of 16 sports for 2017 ASEAN Para Games|publisher=[[The Sun (Malaysia)|The Sun]]}} Previously, Malaysia also hosted the inaugural games in [[2001 ASEAN Para Games|2001]]. Around 1452 athletes participated at the event, which featured 369 events in 16 sports. It was opened by the Prime Minister of Malaysia, [[Najib Razak]] at the [[Bukit Jalil National Stadium]]. The final medal tally was led by Indonesia, followed by host Malaysia and Thailand,{{cite web|url=http://www.themalaymailonline.com/sports/article/nsc-malaysia-met-asean-para-games-target-despite-not-emerging-overall-champ#m84cbgrDlhU47sAg.99|title=NSC: Malaysia met Asean Para Games target despite not emerging overall champs|publisher=[[New Straits Times]]|date=23 September 2017|accessdate=23 September 2017}} while East Timor won its first ever ASEAN Para Games gold medals. Several Games and National records were broken during the games. The Games were deemed generally successful with its effective management of cost spent to host the games, arrangement of public transport and games promotion, commitment in environment conservation and with the rising standard of disabled sports competition amongst the Southeast Asian nations. ==Host city== As per ASEAN Para Games traditions, the games are usually held after every Southeast Asian Games and usually the host country of the Southeast Asian Games is also the host of the ASEAN Para Games. Like the Southeast Asian Games, each country is assigned a year to host but may choose to do so or not. Previously, in July 2012, the SEAGF meeting in [[Myanmar]] confirmed that [[Malaysia]] would host the Southeast Asian Games in 2017, should there be no other country willing to bid for the host job. [[Olympic Council of Malaysia]] (OCM) secretary general Sieh Kok Chi, who attended the meeting, said that [[Myanmar]] would host the Games in 2013, followed by Singapore in 2015. Then it should be [[Brunei]]'s turn but it wanted to host the 2019 Games instead of the 2017 edition. [[Malaysia]] is willing to be the host for the 2017 Games. This means the hosting rights of the ASEAN Para Games automatically goes to Malaysia, which will host the games two weeks after the end of the 2017 Southeast Asian Games. On 12 May 2016, a meeting was held between Olympic Council of Malaysia (OCM) and the Paralympic Council of Malaysia (PCM) to discuss the possibilities of organising the 2017 Southeast Asian Games and the 2017 ASEAN Para Games simultaneously and the merger of the two games.{{cite web|url=http://www.seagames2017.com.my/newscontentah.asp|title=Minister chairs OCM-PCM meeting on Games Merger|work=Official Website}} The same topic was also discussed at the Asean Para Sports Federation Board of Governors meeting on 7 June 2016. By 14 July, the proposal has been rejected by SEA Games Federation (SEAGF) Council, with 9 member countries have opposed the proposal while only two (Malaysia and Laos) agreed, citing the reason for the rejection was due to the tradition and culture that has long been maintained by SEAGF.{{cite web|url=http://www.thesundaily.my/news/1897288|title=SEAGF stands with decision to reject Malaysia's proposal|work=Bernama|publisher=The Sun|date=14 July 2016|accessdate=16 July 2016}} Hence, the date of the 2017 ASEAN Para Games was set from 17 to 23 September 2017. ==Development and preparation== The Malaysia SEA Games Organising Committee (MASOC) is the governing body for the 2017 ASEAN Para Games. It was formed in 2015 to oversee the staging of the event. ===Venues=== {{Location map many |Malaysia West |label1=Kuala Lumpur |marksize=8 |pos=top |lat=3.1357|long=101.688 |label2=Selangor |mark2size=8 |pos2=left |lat2=3.08|long2=101.5 |label3=Negeri Sembilan |mark3size=8 |pos3=left |lat3=2.7166666|long3=101.95 |label4=Putrajaya |mark4size=8 |pos4=right |lat4=2.9430952 |long4=101.699373 |width=200 |float=right |caption=2017 ASEAN Para Games host states }} The 2017 ASEAN Para Games was held around the Klang Valley area, consists of Kuala Lumpur, Selangor, Putrajaya and Negeri Sembilan.{{cite news|title=9th ASEAN Para Games KL2017: Malaysia All Set To Deliver Best Games|url=https://www.kualalumpur2017.com.my/media-newscontent.cshtml?cl=red&bid=512|accessdate=5 September 2017|work=Kuala Lumpur 2017|date=4 September 2017}} All the existing venues in [[National Sports Complex, Malaysia|Bukit Jalil National Sports Complex]] were upgraded while the [[velodrome]], costed MYR 80 million was built in [[Nilai]], [[Negeri Sembilan]] to host track cycling events and was completed on late March 2017 and opened on 26 May 2017.{{cite web|url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/category/nation/2015/06/17/kl-to-be-main-venue-for-2017-sea-games/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150617172439/http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/category/nation/2015/06/17/kl-to-be-main-venue-for-2017-sea-games/|dead-url=yes|archive-date=17 June 2015|title=KL to be main venue for 2017 SEA Games|author=|publisher=Free Malaysia Today|date=17 June 2015|accessdate=17 June 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.kualalumpur2017.com.my/media-newscontent.cshtml?cl=blue&bid=136|title=KL2017: National velodrome gets thumbs up|publisher=Official website}} They were equipped with disabled-friendly facilities prior to the games.{{cite web|url=http://www.thesundaily.my/news/2017/09/11/all-asean-para-games-venues-accommodation-transport-oku-friendly|title=All Asean Para Games venues, accommodation, transport OKU friendly|publisher=The Sun Malaysia}} More than RM1.6 billion has been allocated by the host country to turn the National Sports Complex in Bukit Jalil, Kuala Lumpur, and its surrounding areas into a Sports City.{{cite news|last1=Shah|first1=Mohd Farhan|title=RM1bil allocated to build Sports City|url=http://www.thestar.com.my/Metro/Community/2015/06/03/RM1bil-allocated-to-build-Sports-City/||accessdate=19 November 2015|agency=The Star Online|date=3 June 2015}} The first phase of the work will get the Bukit Jalil National Stadium ready to host the 2017 Southeast Asia Games and the 9th ASEAN Para Games.{{cite news|last1=|first1=|title=MRCB wins bid to regenerate Bukit Jalil sports complex|url=http://www.nst.com.my/news/2015/10/mrcb-wins-bid-regenerate-bukit-jalil-sports-complex||accessdate=19 November 2015|agency=New Straits Times Online|date=28 October 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.kualalumpur2017.com.my/media-newscontent.cshtml?cl=red&bid=524|title=Facilities Near-Completion In Aquatic Centre & MITEC|work=Official website|date=13 September 2017}} A games village was not built. Instead, a "village in the city" concept saw athletes and officials housed in 6 hotels in the area. Besides being physically near to the Sports City, it was hoped that it will add vibe to the nation and reduce post-games costs in converting a dedicated games village to other uses.{{cite web|url=http://kualalumpur2017.com.my/schedule-para.pdf|title=2017 ASEAN Para Games Schedule}} The '''9th ASEAN Para Games''' had 17 venues for the games. 14 in Kuala Lumpur and 1 each in Selangor, Putrajaya and Negeri Sembilan respectively.{{cite web|url=http://www.kualalumpur2017.com.my/media-newscontent.cshtml?cl=yellow&bid=520|title=YB Khairy Issues Rallying Cry, Urges Para Contingent to rise up to challenge}} {| border=1 style="border-collapse:collapse; text-align:left; font-size:100%; border:2px solid #FFCC1B;" |- style="text-align:center; font-weight:bold; background:#145DA5; colour:#FFCC1B;" | {{font colour|gold|State}} | {{font colour|gold|Competition Venue}} | {{font colour|gold|Sports}} |- !rowspan=17|[[Kuala Lumpur]]||colspan=2|[[National Sports Complex, Malaysia]] |- |National Aquatic Centre||Swimming |- |Sintetic Turf Field|| Archery |- |[[Bukit Jalil National Stadium]]|| Athletics, Opening and closing ceremonies |- |[[Axiata Arena]]|| Badminton |- |[[Malaysia National Hockey Stadium]]|| Football 5-a-side |- |Field C||Football 7-a-side |- !colspan=2|Malaysian International Trade & Exhibition Centre (MITEC) |- |Hall 6||Boccia |- |Hall 4||Chess |- |Hall 8||Goalball |- |Hall 3||Powerlifting |- |Hall 7||Table tennis |- |Hall 11||Sitting volleyball |- |Hall 9 and 10||Wheelchair basketball |- !colspan=2|Others |- |National Tennis Centre, Jalan Duta|| Wheelchair tennis |- |'''[[Selangor]]'''||Megalanes, [[Sunway Pyramid]]|| Bowling |- |'''[[Putrajaya]]'''||Putrajaya||Cycling Road |- |'''[[Negeri Sembilan]]'''||Nilai Velodrome and BMX Circuit||Cycling Track |} ===Public transport=== Prasarana became one of the 2017 ASEAN Para Games sponsors as “Official Public Transport Service Provider” on 9 May 2017 during the SEA Games 100-days countdown celebration.{{cite web|url=https://www.kualalumpur2017.com.my/media-newscontent.cshtml?cl=red&bid=144|title=KL2017: 100-day countdown begins, MASOC enters final phase of preparation|publisher=Official website|date=9 May 2017|accessdate=9 May 2017}} The company provided 60 buses for the participating athletes throughout the games and cars for technical officers and guests.{{cite web|url=http://www.thesundaily.my/news/2017/09/04/103-gold-medals-target-9th-asean-para-games|title=103 gold medals target for 9th Asean Para Games|publisher=[[The Sun (Malaysia)|The Sun]]|date=4 September 2017}} ===Volunteers=== The organisers estimated that about 20,000 volunteers are needed to successfully host the SEA games and the ASEAN Para Games. They were tasked with a variety of duties, such as scorekeeping, crowd control, ticketing, promotions. Volunteer recruitment began on 14 November 2015, the same date as the launch party of the games logo, theme and mascot until July 2017,{{cite web|url=http://www.thestar.com.my/news/nation/2015/11/16/20000-volunteers-needed-for-2017-sea-games/|title=20,000 volunteers needed for 2017 SEA Games|publisher=The Star|date=16 November 2015|accessdate=30 December 2015}} in which 50,000 people have signed up as volunteers. The Games Volunteer Program was held at the [[National University of Malaysia]] in Bangi in four phases from February to June.{{cite web|url=http://kualalumpur2017.com.my/media-newscontent.cshtml?cl=red&bid=157|title=KL2017: 2,000 volunteers for opening and closing ceremonies|publisher=Official website|date=20 May 2017|accessdate=20 May 2017}} On 19 July 2017, of the 50,000 online applicants, 13,000 people were selected to be the games volunteer. 9,000 people were chosen to be the volunteer of the 2017 Southeast Asian Games, whereas another 4,000 people were chosen to be the volunteer of the 2017 ASEAN Para Games.{{cite web|url=http://www.kualalumpur2017.com.my/media-newscontent.cshtml?cl=red&bid=201|title=Volunteers can't wait for games to began|publisher=Official website|date=19 July 2017|accessdate=19 July 2017}} ===Ticketing=== On 4 July 2017, it was announced that no paid tickets are required for the ASEAN Para Games events and the entry to the games' venues is entirely free.{{cite web|url=http://www.kualalumpur2017.com.my/media-presscontent.cshtml?cl=red&bid=43|title=Kuala Lumpur 2017 tickets now on sale}} ===Countdown=== During the closing ceremony of the [[2015 ASEAN Para Games]], the ASEAN Para Sports Federation Flag was formally handed over to Malaysia from Singapore. This was followed by a song and dance section highlighting Malaysia as the next venue. On 14 November 2015, a launch party was held at the [[Suria KLCC]] to launch the logo, mascot and the volunteer recruitment programme. On 19 August 2016, a series of festivities, dubbed the "Wau Factor" were held at the National Sports Council Centre in Setiawangsa, to mark the one-year countdown to the games.{{cite web|url=http://www.kualalumpur2017.com.my/newscontentbc.asp|title=Wau Factor Celebrates A Year To Go To Sea Games 2017|work=Official website}} From 2 March to 20 May 2017 Malaysia SEA Games organising committee organised a school tour programme dubbed the KL2017@Schools programme at 33 selected schools across Peninsular Malaysia to instill awareness about the games amongst the school students.{{cite web|url=http://www.kualalumpur2017.com.my/media-newscontent.cshtml?cl=red&bid=108|title=KL2017 Fever Grips Schools|publisher=Official Website|date=14 May 2017}} On 9 May 2017, Malaysia SEA Games Organising committee organised a major countdown event at [[KL Sentral]] to mark the 100-day countdown in a few days which was attended by athletes, officials, Para athletes, stakeholders, sponsors and volunteers.{{cite web|url=http://kualalumpur2017.com.my/media-newscontent.cshtml?cl=red&bid=144|title=KL2017: 100-Day Countdown Begins, MASOC Enters Final Phase Of Preparation|date=9 May 2017|publisher=Official Website}} After that, various individuals and organisations marked the games countdown through a video tribute. This included: Kyopropaganda and Malaysia SEA Games Organising Committee (100, 100-people mass exercise), Ipan Bender (90, 90 High Fives), Intan Sarah and National Women Futsal teammates (80, Ball-juggling 80 times), Aminemo and the Royal Malaysian Police Personnel (70, 70 times push-ups in 7 different ways), Superpandy, Farhan Kapoor and the scouts (60, Building a tower of bottles in 60 seconds using 100 Plus bottles), Joseph Germani and Malaysia Basketball Association trainees (50, score 50 basketball shots), Olivia Shyan and the SK Taman Megah students (40, plant 40 plants), Ahmad Aiman and 30 locals (30, 30-people teh tarik relay), Muhammad Rezza, Akwa Ariffin and 20 tai-chi practitioners (20, doing Tai Chi with 20 practitioners), Joseph Germani and the [[Fire and Rescue Department of Malaysia]] personnel (10, doing 10 times burpees), Farhan Hadi, Preston Les and Tanesh (3, doing three-legged race), Ain Suhada and Iqbal Harun (2, Exercise with a Partner) and Miss Alvy, Yasmin Matthews, Khor Adrian and Raj Mahal (1, paint a number 1 sculpture bearing the stripes of the games logo with a group of people). ===Security=== The principal agency to ensure the security of the games is the [[Royal Malaysian Police]] Force. Six drills were held to prepare the police force to face any unpredicted situations.{{cite web|url=http://www.kualalumpur2017.com.my/media-newscontent.cshtml?cl=red&bid=190|title=KL2017: Police ready for any eventualities|date=12 July 2017}} ===Medals=== [[File:2017 SEA Games medals.jpeg|thumb|right|Kuala Lumpur 2017 medals.]] Similar to the [[2017 Southeast Asian Games]], the medals of the games were designed by [[Royal Selangor]], which is also the designer company for the torch and the baton. They were announced on 30 May 2017, the same day [[Royal Selangor]] announced as one of the games main sponsor which made MASOC's sponsorship total RM82.6 million, exceeded its sponsorship target of RM80 million.{{cite web|url=http://www.kualalumpur2017.com.my/media-newscontent.cshtml?cl=red&bid=169|title=Royal Selangor Comes On Board, KL2017 Exceed Sponsorship Target|date=30 May 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://www.thelevel.my/royal-selangor-unveils-kuala-lumpur-2017-games-medals-merchandises/|title=Royal Selangor unveils Kuala Lumpur 2017 merchandises}}{{cite web|url=http://www.kualalumpur2017.com.my/media-presscontent.cshtml?cl=yellow&bid=38|title=MASOC Scores Another Sponsorship: Royal Selangor Designs Kuala Lumpur 2017 Medals|date=30 May 2017}} The medals have subtle curved surfaces, rims and edges, and are made of pewter with a disc of kempas wood integrated into the design. They featured the ASEAN Para Sports Federation logo on the obverse, and the games logo on the reverse. ===Baton relay=== [[File:2017 Southeast Asian Games baton.png|thumb|right|Baton of the Games.]] The games baton relay dubbed the Rising Together Baton Run, shares the same route as the baton relay of the [[2017 Southeast Asian Games]] and is the first of its kind in the history of ASEAN Para Games. It covered a distance of 10 kilometres on average in the 10 capital cities of the Southeast Asian Region countries, excluding the host country, passing through the landmarks of each countries' capital city. The baton relay began with Brunei on 5 March 2017,{{cite web|url=http://www.kualalumpur2017.com.my/media-newscontent.cshtml?cl=blue&bid=102|title=YB Khairy launches Rising Together Baton Run to warm reception in Brunei|publisher=Official website|date=5 March 2017|accessdate=6 March 2017}} followed by the Philippines on 12 March,{{cite web|url=http://www.kualalumpur2017.com.my/media-newscontent.cshtml?cl=yellow&bid=104|title=Carnival-like atmosphere as Rising Together-Baton Run hits Philippines|publisher=Official website|date=12 March 2017|accessdate=13 March 2017}} Laos on 18 March,{{cite web|url=http://www.kualalumpur2017.com.my/media-newscontent.cshtml?cl=green&bid=112|title=Iconic monuments marked Lao PDR's Rising Together Baton Run|publisher=Official website|date=18 March 2017|accessdate=19 March 2017}} Myanmar on 25 March,{{cite web|url=http://www.kualalumpur2017.com.my/media-newscontent.cshtml?cl=green&bid=118|title=Grand Shwedagon Pagoda provides perfect backdrop for Baton Run in Myanmar|publisher=Official website|date=25 March 2017|accessdate=26 March 2017}} Thailand on 1 April,{{cite web|url=http://www.kualalumpur2017.com.my/media-newscontent.cshtml?cl=red&bid=124|title=Longest Bangkok Stage as Rising Together Baton Run completes halfway point|publisher=Official website|date=1 April 2017|accessdate=2 April 2017}} Vietnam on 9 April,{{cite web|url=http://www.kualalumpur2017.com.my/media-newscontent.cshtml?cl=red&bid=129|title=Xuan Vinh the star as Rising Together Baton Run sizzles into Vietnam|publisher=Official website|date=9 April 2017|accessdate=10 April 2017}} East Timor on 17 April,{{cite web|url=http://www.kualalumpur2017.com.my/media-newscontent.cshtml?cl=blue&bid=135|title=‘Obrigado’ as Rising Together Baton Run Lights Up spirited Timor-Leste|publisher=Official website|date=17 April 2017|accessdate=18 April 2017}} Cambodia on 22 April{{cite web|url=http://www.kualalumpur2017.com.my/media-newscontent.cshtml?cl=red&bid=138|title=Seavmey and Sreymom give credence to Baton Run in Cambodia|publisher=Official website|date=22 April 2017|accessdate=22 April 2017}} and Indonesia on 30 April{{cite web|url=http://www.kualalumpur2017.com.my/media-newscontent.cshtml?cl=green&bid=142|title=Car-free Jakarta embraces penultimate stage of Rising Together Baton Run|publisher=Official website|date=30 April 2017|accessdate=30 April 2017}} and ended with Singapore on 13 May 2017.{{cite web|url=http://www.kualalumpur2017.com.my/ceremonies-batonrun.cshtml|title=About Baton Run|publisher=Official website|accessdate=10 May 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.kualalumpur2017.com.my/media-newscontent.cshtml?cl=red&bid=152|title=Baton run reaches climax, concludes in S'pore|publisher=Official website|date=13 May 2017|accessdate=15 May 2017}} The games baton was designed by [[Royal Selangor]] which sold the baton to the public at MYR 1480 and its design was inspired by the games' theme, rising together. Its design depicts shards and a triangular cross section. The baton has a length of 400 mm, a width of 44 mm, weighs approximately 600g and made up of materials which are a stave in kempas, a tawny wood native to Southeast Asia, and a satin-finished pewter finial. {{Clr}} {{location map+|Southeast Asia|overlay_image=Southeast Asia plus Timor Leste location map.svg|float=center|width=800|caption=2017 ASEAN Para Games baton relay route. {{col-begin}} |position=top}} }} ===Torch relay=== [[File:2017 Southeast Asian Games torch.png|thumb|right|Torch of the Games]] The same day the baton relay ended in Singapore, the torch relay was held across the country began with the state of Johor until 18 May 2017,{{cite web|url=http://www.kualalumpur2017.com.my/media-newscontent.cshtml?cl=red&bid=153|title=Rising Together with KL 2017 torch run|publisher=Official website|date=13 May 2017}} followed by Malacca from 18 to 21 May 2017,{{cite web|url=http://www.kualalumpur2017.com.my/media-newscontent.cshtml?cl=green&bid=158|title=KL2017 Torch on cruise boat ride down Malacca River |publisher=Official website|date=20 May 2017}} Negeri Sembilan from 22 to 25 May, Labuan from 3 to 4 June, Sabah from 5 to 8 June, Sarawak from 8 to 13 June, Perlis from 15 to 17 June, Kedah from 17 to 20 June, Penang from 3 to 6 July, Perak from 7 to 12 July, Kelantan from 13 to 17 July, Terengganu from 17 to 23 July, Pahang from 24 to 30 July, Selangor from 31 July to 5 August, Putrajaya on 6 August and ended with the host city Kuala Lumpur on 12 August 2017. The games torch has a length of 125 mm, width of 86 mm and a height of 850 mm and weighs 2 kg with fuel and 1.8 kg without fuel. Like the baton, the torch was designed too by Royal Selangor. It has a sleek custom-milled combustion chamber and a triangular cross section which symbolises strength in unity and has the games logo and motto, the SEA Games and the ASEAN Para Games logo emblazoned on it.{{cite web|url=https://www.kualalumpur2017.com.my/media-presscontent.cshtml?cl=green&bid=23|title=Kuala Lumpur 2017 Torch Run Fuels the sporting spirit across the nation|date=7 April 2017|publisher=Official Website}} {{Clr}} {{location map+|Malaysia|float=center|width=800|caption=2017 ASEAN Para Games torch relay route. {{col-begin}} {{col-3}} ;May 13–18 :{{0}}1. map~|Malaysia|position=left|lat=3.08|long=101.5|label='''[[Selangor|14]]'''}} {{Location map~|Malaysia|position=below|lat=2.94|long=101.7|label='''[[Putrajaya|15]]'''}} {{Location map~|Malaysia|position=top|lat=3.1357|long=101.688|label='''[[Kuala Lumpur|16]]'''}} }} ===Sustainability=== As an aspect of staging the games, the Games organising committee committed to a focus on sustainability and environmental protection by launching the Kuala Lumpur 2017 Green Initiatives on 5 June 2017.{{cite web|url=https://www.kualalumpur2017.com.my/media-newscontent.cshtml?cl=red&bid=171|title=KL2017: Paving way for future green games|publisher=Official website|date=5 June 2017|accessdate=29 August 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://www.kualalumpur2017.com.my/about-greeninitiatives.cshtml|title=Green Initiatives|publisher=Official website}} Among the activities of the initiative is the ‘One Medal, One Tree’ programme aimed at having a total of 5,249 trees be planted in and around Kuala Lumpur Sports City, one for each medal awarded to winning athlete during the games which is divided into three phases.{{cite web|url=https://www.kualalumpur2017.com.my/media-newscontent.cshtml?cl=blue&bid=212|title=‘One medal, One tree’ Part of green initiatives for KL2017|publisher=Kuala Lumpur 2017|date=2 August 2017|accessdate=29 August 2017}} Other activities included providing waste recycling bins at games' main venue, providing public transportation and providing electric car facilities at selected spots of the games' main venue. ==Marketing== [[File:2017 SEA games mascot.png|thumb|right|''Rimau'', the Malayan tiger, the official mascot.]] [[File:Kuala Lumpur 2017 logo.png|thumb|''Wau'', the logo of Kuala Lumpur 2017 ([[2017 Southeast Asian Games|SEA Games]] combined with ASEAN Para Games). ]] ===Motto=== Similar to the 2017 Southeast Asian Games, the official motto of the 2017 ASEAN Para Games is "Rising Together" or "''Bangkit Bersama''" in Malay.{{cite web|title=Baton Run to Support the 29th SEA Games, Kuala Lumpur 2017|url=http://www.olympiclao.org/index.php/en/news-events/93-slides1/174-baton-run-to-support-the-29th-sea-games-kuala-lumpur-2017|website=Lao National Olympic Committee|accessdate=6 August 2017}} It was chosen to highlight unity between the nations in Southeast Asia as well as to signify the Kuala Lumpur games as the first ASEAN Para Games to be held after the formation of the ASEAN Community in 2015.{{cite news|title=Sea Games 2017: Rising Together As One|url=http://www.visionkl.com/rising-together-one-2/|accessdate=6 August 2017|work=Vision KL}} ===Logo=== Similar to the 2017 Southeast Asian Games, the logo of the 2017 ASEAN Para Games is an image of a [[Wau Bulan]], a crescent-shaped kite traditionally popular on the east coast of [[Peninsular Malaysia]]. The combination of stripes and colours of the logo were derived from the flags of all countries in Southeast Asia. A nationwide competition was held to select the logo of the games which saw a total of 174 entries submitted for the design competition.{{cite web|url=http://www.nst.com.my/news/2015/11/111481/rising-together-rimau-drive-kl-sea-games|title=Rising together, Rimau to drive KL Sea Games|publisher=New Straits Times|date=14 November 2015|accessdate=19 November 2015}} The Kuala Lumpur 2017 logo, made by combining the games' logo with the logo of [[2017 Southeast Asian Games]] is sometimes used by the organisers to reflect the common relationship as Parallel games of one another with SEA Games being held for the able-bodied athletes and the ASEAN Para games held for the disabled athletes. ===Mascot=== Similar to the 2017 Southeast Asian Games, the official mascot of the 2017 ASEAN Para Games is an anthropomorphic [[Malayan tiger]] named ''Rimau''. It was unveiled on 14 November 2015, together with the games' logo and theme. The mascot's name is not only a Malay word for Tiger, but also an abbreviation of the games' core values, namely: Respect, Integrity, Move, Attitude and Unity. He is described as a gracious, friendly, competitive and athletic athlete.{{cite web|url=http://www.kualalumpur2017.com.my/about-brandmascot.cshtml|title=About Brand and mascot- Official Website|date=14 November 2015|accessdate=14 November 2015|work=Official Website|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170117185744/http://www.kualalumpur2017.com.my/about-brandmascot.cshtml|archive-date=2017-01-17|dead-url=yes|df=}} ===Songs=== The 2017 ASEAN Para Games had 4 theme songs. During the 100 day countdown to SEA Games celebration on 9 May 2017, Malaysians were requested by singer [[Dayang Nurfaizah]] and composer Ramli MS to submit their ideas and stories related to the games' theme "Rising Together" to social network websites through a crowdsourcing campaign to enable them to create the games theme song. On 8 August 2017, one theme song for the games has been released and is entitled "Rising Together" (Bangkit Bersama).{{cite web|url=http://www.kualalumpur2017.com.my/about-songs.cshtml|title=Song #BangkitBersama|publisher=Official website|accessdate=8 August 2017}} On 2 August 2017, a theme song titled "Tunjuk Belang" (Show The Stripes) was released. It was performed by monoloQue, Azlan Typewriter and maliQue. The song is described as a rock song which merges "traditional and modern sounds".{{cite web|url=http://www.rojakdaily.com/entertainment/article/3115/have-you-heard-the-official-theme-song-for-sea-games-2017|title=Have You Heard The Official Theme Song For SEA Games 2017?|author=Jessica Chua|publisher=Rojak Daily|date=2 August 2017|accessdate=6 August 2017}} The composer and producer of the song is maliQue.{{cite web|url=http://www.thehive.asia/2017/08/sea-games-2017-reveals-its-theme-song.html|title=SEA Games 2017 reveals its theme song|author=Erny Suzira|publisher=The Hive Asia|date=2 August 2017|accessdate=6 August 2017}} The title of the song literally means showing off one's true colours in English and "Belang" means stripes alluding to the mascot of the games, shown above. Another theme song was released earlier on 13 July 2017, titled "So Many Hands" (Tangan-Tangan Yang Menjulang) and was performed by Mia Palencia in English and Asmidar in Malay which is the song of the Kuala Lumpur 2017 Promo Video, "It Takes a Nation to Raise a Champion" (Bersama Kita Lahirkan Juara).{{cite web|url=http://kualalumpur2017.com.my/media-newscontent.cshtml?cl=green&bid=227|title=KL 2017: “Bangkit Bersama” theme song launched, Pavilion joins KL2017|publisher=Official website|date=8 August 2017|accessdate=8 August 2017}} A closing theme song for the Games, "Together We Rise" was released on 30 August 2017. It was performed by Vince Chong and Jaclyn Victor. ===Sponsors=== Like the 2017 Southeast Asian Games, Dentsu Sports Asia, a subsidiary of [[Dentsu]] and the Sportswork Group are the [[sponsorship]] agencies of the 2017 ASEAN Para Games. The partnership of the two firms were announced in January 2016.{{cite news|title=FYIDentsu appointed as sponsorship agency for 2017 SEA Games in Malaysia|url=http://www.mumbrella.asia/2016/06/dentsu-appointed-as-sponsorship-agency-for-2017-sea-games-in-malaysia/|accessdate=13 July 2017|work=Mumbrella Asia|date=24 June 2016}} Dentsu is responsible for manages sponsorship matters involving international and Malaysian firms while Sportswork manages Malaysian government linked companies{{cite news|title=Ajinomoto Platinum Sponsor for the upcoming SEA Games|url=http://www.marketingmagazine.com.my/breaking-news/breaking-news/daily-fresh-news/ajinomoto-platinum-sponsor-for-the-upcoming-sea-games|accessdate=13 July 2017|work=Marketing Magazine|publisher=Sledgehammer Communications (M) Sdn Bhd.|date=14 February 2017}} There are four tiers of sponsorship depending on the amount of funds a company contributes to the games. Bronze sponsors contributed [[Malaysian ringgit|RM]]1 million or less, Silver sponsors contributed RM1 to 3 million. Gold sponsors contributed RM3 to 7.5 million and Platinum sponsors contributed RM7.5 to 15 million.{{cite news|title=Masoc close to achieving RM80mil Games sponsorship|url=http://www.thestar.com.my/sport/other-sport/2017/03/21/masoc-close-to-achieving-rm80mil-games-sponsorship/|accessdate=13 July 2017|work=The Star|date=21 March 2017}} A total of 39 sponsors, comprising 6 Platinum sponsors, 6 Gold sponsors, 9 Silver sponsors and 18 Bronze sponsors, contributed to the 2017 ASEAN Para Games. {|class="wikitable" !colspan=2|2017 ASEAN Para Games Corporation Sdn. Bhd.|date=26 May 2017}}{{cite news|title=Grab remains as the sponsor for SEA Games – KJ|url=http://malaysiagazette.com/v2/en/2017/05/30/grab-remains-sponsor-sea-games-kj/|accessdate=13 July 2017|work=Malaysia Gazette|date=30 May 2017}} [[Tenaga Nasional]], [[Sony]] ([[Sony Music]]) |- |'''Silver''' |[[100Plus]], [[Milo (drink)|Milo]], SCGM BHD–Benxon, [[Prudential plc|Prudential]], [[McDonald's]],{{cite news|last1=Krishnan|first1=Gowri|title=McDonald’s sign RM 1million sponsorship deal with 29th SEA Games|url=https://www.fourthofficial.com/2017/45801/mcdonalds-sign-rm-1million-sponsorship-deal-29th-sea-games/|accessdate=13 July 2017|work=FourthOfficial.com|publisher=Vijandren Ramadaas|date=25 April 2017}} Spritzer,{{cite news|last1=Tan|first1=Ming Wai|title=Spritzer back as Silver sponsor for SEA Games|url=http://www.thestar.com.my/sport/other-sport/2017/05/12/spritzer-back-as-silver-sponsor-for-sea-games/|accessdate=13 July 2017|work=The Star|date=12 May 2017}} [[Pavilion Kuala Lumpur|Pavilion KL]], [[Royal Selangor]], [[AEON (company)|AEON Malaysia]] |- |'''Bronze''' |Double Happiness, [[Gloria Jean's Coffees]], [[JVC Kenwood]], [[La Martina]], Maha Mas Medic, Maju Group, Marathon Thailand, Maxwin, [[Mikasa Sports|Mikasa-Sunrise]], MLS-Zimmer-Airflex, [[Molten Corporation]], [[MRCB]], Nittaku, [[Otto Bock]], Sunstar, Trybe, Victor, Wiraka |} ==The Games== ===Opening ceremony=== The opening ceremony was held in [[Bukit Jalil National Stadium]] on 17 September 2017 at 20:17 [[Malaysian Standard Time|MST]] ([[UTC+08:00|UTC+8]]) which highlighted aspects of disabled people overcoming challenges in life. The ceremony was directed by film director [[Saw Teong Hin]] alongside the Memories Entertainment creative team with co-operation from the [[Malaysian Armed Forces]].{{cite web|url=http://www.themalaysianinsight.com/s/15049/|title=PM opens 9th Para Asean Games|newspaper=Malaysian insight|date=18 September 2017|accessdate=18 September 2017}} The time 20:17 was chosen to start the opening ceremony to mark the year 2017, the year which Malaysia hosted the 9th ASEAN Para Games.{{cite web|url=http://www.thestar.com.my/news/nation/2017/09/18/a-breathtaking-opening-for-the-9th-asean-para-games/|title=A breathtaking opening for the 9th Asean Para Games|work=The Star|date=18 September 2017}} A minute of silence was held before the ceremony to mourn the passing of the 14th Yang di-Pertuan Agong and the 28th Sultan of Kedah, [[Abdul Halim of Kedah|Sultan Abdul Halim]] and the victims of the Tahfiz Darul Quran Ittifaqiyah religious school fire in Petaling Jaya. The ceremony begins with the arrival of the Prime Minister of Malaysia, [[Najib Razak]] and his wife [[Rosmah Mansor]]. The National Anthem of Malaysia, [[Negaraku]] was performed by [[Malaysian Armed Forces]] band as the national flag was raised. This was followed by the countdown projection, the video of several Malaysian children carrying the flags of the participating nations and the projection of the games logo on the stage centre. After that, the national flags of the participating nations, the ASEAN Para Sports Federation flag and the edition flag, were brought into the stadium to symbolise the welcoming of the participants by Malaysia, the games' host nation. "Rimau", the mascot of the Games then entered the stadium in a wheelchair after the Volunteers form the shape of the mascot's head as the projection of the mascot's head appears on the stage centre. [[File:Philippines 2017 ASEAN ParaGames delegate opening.jpg|thumb|right|Parade of nations at the Opening ceremony of the 9th ASEAN Para Games.]] Next, the parade of athletes from all 11 competing nations started with Brunei leading the field in alphabetical order and ended with the host nation, Malaysia entering the stadium last. The Bruneian contingent was led by Sahri bin Hj Jumaat of Athletics. The Cambodian contingent was led by Yav Vannak of Swimming. The Indonesian contingent was led by Anto Boi of Powerlifting. The Lao contingent was led by Pia of Powerlifting. The Myanmar contingent was led by Si Thu Min of Table tennis. The Filipino contingent was led by Menandro Junni Redor of Chess. The Singaporean contingent was led by Suhairi Bin Suhani of Athletics. The Thai contingent was led by Wannaruemon Kewalin of Athletics. The East Timorese contingent was led by Maria Julieta A Da Cruz of Boccia. The Vietnamese contingent was led by Le Van Cong of Powerlifting. Meanwhile, the Malaysian contingent was led by the unprecedented duo of [[2016 Summer Paralympics]] gold medalists, [[Muhammad Ziyad Zolkefli]] and [[Abdul Latif Romly]]. A video featuring Malaysian notable Paralympic athletes and rapper Aman RA entitled I am Here was also shown.{{cite web|url=https://www.nst.com.my/sports/others/2017/09/280848/2017-kuala-lumpur-asean-para-games-kicks|title=2017 Kuala Lumpur ASEAN Para Games kicks-off|work=New Straits Times}} The 10-minute performance of the ceremony, We Are One told the story of the disabled people desire of integration into the society. It featured violin performance by Malaysian Para Swimmer and Violinist Yeo Yi Lin, sape performance by Alena Murang and Stephen Kayang, Bamboo flute performance by Ramlan Koyok and piano performance by Clarence Kang. [[Yuna (singer)|Yuna]] makes her appearance at the stadium, performed the song, Rescue accompanied by performers and dancers on stage, from The Beautiful Gate Foundation, Malaysian Down Syndrome Society, United Voice Self Advocacy Society of Persons with Learning Disabilities Selangor & Kuala Lumpur, Pusat Penjagaan Kanak-Kanak Cacat Taman Megah and Farah Sulaiman Dancing Troupe. In keeping with tradition, welcoming speeches were given by the President of the ASEAN Para Sports Federation Osoth Bhavilai and Malaysia's Youth and Sports Minister Khairy Jamaluddin. The former and current Paralympic medalists, national sportsmen and sportswomen Mohamad Khasseri Othman, Perumal Mariappan, Nabilah Ahmad Sharif, Cheok Kon Fatt, Norhayati Sanoh, Siow Lee Chan, Felicia Mikat, Zul Amirul Sidi Abdullah, Hemala Devi Enikutty, Faridul Masri and Siti Nor Liasah Mohd Ariffin leaded the Royal Malaysian Navy Personnel who carried the Games Federation flag and the games edition flag into the stadium. The flags were then raised by the Navy personnel at the centre stage. After that, Prime Minister Najib declared the games opened. Sharifah Raudzah Syed Akil took the oath for athletes, while Teo Kian Joo took the oath for the judges. The cauldron was lit by Hasihin Sanawi, 2012 Summer Paralympics Archery bronze medalist with support from Para cycling World championship bronze medalist Muhammad Afiq Afify, 2015 ASEAN Para Games athletics silver medalist Krishna Kumar Haridas, 2016 Summer Paralympics Bronze medalist Noor Radiah Ismail and 2015 ASEAN Para Games swimming Gold medalist Fraidden Dawan. Hasihin lit the torch flame on the cauldron's segment which is suspended by wire, while Afify, Krishna, Noor and Fraidden move the pedal to push the segment towards the cauldron along the wire. The cauldron of the Games is similar to the 2017 Southeast Asian Games' cauldron. Its design was inspired by the traditional Malaysian oil torches used to welcome guests during festivals, and was to symbolise national unity. It had five spokes inscribed with the Rukun Negara and the colour gold served to honour Malaysia’s monarch, as well as a nod to the highest award at the biennial games. The ceremony concluded with a colourful fireworks display erupted over the National Stadium, signalling the official commencement of the Games.[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hCUwouHpt6k Opening ceremony] ===Closing ceremony=== The closing ceremony was held in Bukit Jalil National Stadium on 23 September 2017 at 20:30 MST (UTC+8). Like the opening ceremony, the closing ceremony was directed by film director [[Saw Teong Hin]] alongside the Memories Entertainment creative team with co-operation from the Malaysian Armed Forces.{{cite web|url=https://www.nst.com.my/sports/others/2017/09/283260/9th-asean-para-games-wraps-high-note|title=9th Asean Para Games wraps up on high note|author=Justin Ong|publisher=New Straits Times|date=23 September 2017|accessdate=23 September 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://english.astroawani.com/malaysia-news/apg-kl2017-spectacular-closing-ceremony-seagf-flag-goes-manila-156031|title=APG KL2017: Spectacular closing ceremony as APSF flag goes to Manila|publisher=[[Astro Awani]]|date=23 September 2017|accessdate=23 September 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.thestar.com.my/news/nation/2017/09/24/closing-display-worthy-of-athletes-spirit-asean-para-games-ends-on-euphoric-note-with-all-taking-par/|title=Asean Para Games ends on euphoric note with all taking part honoured|publisher=[[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]]|date=23 September 2017|accessdate=23 September 2017}} The ceremony begins with the arrival of the Deputy Prime Minister of Malaysia, [[Ahmad Zahid Hamidi]]. The National Anthem of Malaysia, [[Negaraku]] was performed by [[Malaysian Armed Forces]] band as the national flag was raised. Flags of the participating nations, the Federation flag and the Games edition flag were brought into the stadium. This was followed by the parade of athletes from 11 nations and Rimau entering the stage with Malaysia entering the stadium last. The parade of volunteers started with the volunteers dancing to [[Faizal Tahir]]'s hit single, "Gemuruh", followed by a video shot of several volunteers and top para athletes and Minister of Youth and Sports, [[Khairy Jamaluddin]]. A cultural performance titled "Sama-sama", a sign of gratitude for Malaysia being given the opportunity to host the games, was presented.{{cite web|url=https://kualalumpur2017.com.my/media-newscontent.cshtml?cl=red&bid=609|title=Colourful Ceremony marks end of games|publisher=Official website|date=24 September 2017}} Closing speeches were given by the President of the Malaysia Paralympic Council, SM Nasarudin SM Nasimuddin and ASEAN Para Sports Federation President, Osoth Bhavilai. Deputy Prime Minister of Malaysia Ahmad Zahid Hamidi then declared the 2017 ASEAN Para Games closed. A video about the participating athletes performing throughout the games, featuring some Malaysian sports medalists and their coaches with Jaclyn Victor and Vince Chong song, "Together We Rise" as background music, was played followed by the extinguishing of the cauldron and the lowering of the APSF flag by the Royal Malaysian Navy. The ASEAN Para Sports Federation flag was handed over from the Malaysian Paralympic Council President to the Philippines Paralympic Council President, Michael I. Barredo through Minister of the Youth and Sports of Malaysia, and APSF President. The National Anthem of the Philippines, [[Lupang Hinirang]] was played and the Philippines flag was raised, symbolising the hosting responsibilities being passed to Philippines. A video of the Philippines tourism featuring Philippines Para athletes was later shown. The ceremony concluded with a special concert by Yuna and fireworks erupted over the stadium, signalling the official conclusion of the games.[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EHU2t4CyozE Closing ceremony] ===Participating nations=== Some 1,452 athletes from all 11 ASEAN countries participated in the Games. East Timor returned to compete at the ASEAN Para Games for the first time since [[2011 ASEAN Para Games|2011]] after its suspension by the International Paralympic Committee had been lifted, enabled it to compete at the [[East Timor at the 2016 Summer Paralympics|Rio Paralympic Games]] a year ago. {{Div col|colwidth=22em}} * {{flag|Brunei}} (27) * {{flag|Cambodia}} (75) * {{flag|Indonesia}} (192) (Paralympics).svg|20px]] [[Wheelchair tennis at the 2017 ASEAN Para Games|Wheelchair tennis]] (3) {{col-end}} ===Calendar=== {{2017 ASEAN Para Games calendar}} ===Medal table=== The 2017 ASEAN Para Games featured 369 events, resulting in 369 medal sets to be distributed. Two bronze medals were awarded in most events in racket sports: 11 in [[Badminton at the 2017 ASEAN Para Games|Badminton]], 18 in Table tennis and 3 in [[Wheelchair tennis at the 2017 ASEAN Para Games|Wheelchair tennis]]. Furthermore, there was a third-place tie in the [[Bowling at the 2017 ASEAN Para Games|Bowling mixed doubles TPB8+TPB8 event]], giving a total of 33 additional bronze medals. On the other hand, 7 silver and 28 bronze medals were not awarded in 28 events in 6 sports competed at the games due to few number of participants. These are: [[Athletics at the 2017 ASEAN Para Games|Athletics]] (2 silver and 9 bronze), [[Boccia at the 2017 ASEAN Para Games|Boccia]] (1 bronze), [[Cycling at the 2017 ASEAN Para Games|Cycling]] (2 silver and 4 bronze), [[Powerlifting at the 2017 ASEAN Para Games|Powerlifting]] (1 silver and 5 bronze), [[Swimming at the 2017 ASEAN Para Games|Swimming]] (2 silver and 7 bronze) and [[Table tennis at the 2017 ASEAN Para Games|Table tennis]] (2 bronze). As a result, a total of 1105 medals comprising 369 gold medals, 362 silver medals and 374 bronze medals were awarded to athletes. The Host Malaysia's performance was their third best in ASEAN Para Games History and was second behind Indonesia as overall Champion. Meanwhile, despite small contingent size, East Timor managed to win its first ever ASEAN Para Games gold medals, all 2 of them are from athletics. {{2017 ASEAN Para Games medal table}} ==Broadcasting== The organiser hosted the live video stream at its YouTube channel for the opening and closing ceremonies and 5 sport events namely, Swimming, Cycling, Powerlifting, Athletics and Wheelchair basketball.{{cite web|url=http://kualalumpur2017.com.my/pdf/announcement/para/oc_reminder_en.pdf|title=Public Reminder - Opening Ceremony}} An official mobile application for the games was also released which featured live streams of selected sports events, schedules, results and other promotional materials.{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCLEwl4YV5KFinhH0cNK0Zpw|title=Kuala Lumpur 2017|website=Youtube}}{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/story.php?story_fbid=1971444776461634&id=1446847348921382|title=Live streaming information|website=Facebook}} [[Radio Televisyen Malaysia]] (RTM TV1) and [[People's Television Network]] (PTV-4) serves as the official broadcaster of the games in Malaysia and the Philippines respectively.{{cite news|url=http://paragames.ptv.ph/pcoo-covers-ph-athletes-in-9th-asean-para-games-september-17-2017/|title=PCOO Covers PH Athletes In 9th ASEAN Para Games September 17, 2017|publisher=PTV|date=September 17, 2017|accessdate=September 17, 2017}} ==See also== * [[2017 Southeast Asian Games]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.kualalumpur2017.com.my/ 2017 ASEAN Para Games Official Website] * [http://gms.kualalumpur2017.com.my/RS2017P/ 2017 ASEAN Para Games Official Website Result System Site] {{S-start}} {{Succession box|title=''[[ASEAN Para Games]]''
[[Kuala Lumpur]]|before=[[2015 ASEAN Para Games|Singapore]]|after=[[2020 ASEAN Para Games|Philippines]]|years=''IX ASEAN Para Games'' (2017)}} {{S-end}} {{Events at the 2017 ASEAN Para Games}} {{Nations at the 2017 ASEAN Para Games}} {{ASEAN Para Games}} [[Category:2017 in multi-sport events|ASEAN ParaGames]] [[Category:ASEAN Para Games]] [[Category:2017 in Asian sport]] [[Category:2017 in Malaysian sport]] [[Category:Multi-sport events in Malaysia]] [[Category:Sport in Kuala Lumpur]] [[Category:International sports competitions hosted by Malaysia]] [[Category:2017 ASEAN Para Games| ]] [[Category:September 2017 sports events in Asia|ASEAN Para Games]]

revision.text:
{{multiple issues| {{cleanup reorganize|date=July 2013}} {{refimprove|date=December 2010}} }} [[File:AperturaClausura.svg|thumb|250px| {{legend|#f7941d|Apertura and Clausura tournaments during calendar year}} {{legend|#39b54a|Apertura and Clausura starting in the second half of calendar year and finishing at the first half of following year}} {{legend|#00aeef|Apertura and Clausura are only parts of a larger tournament}} ]] The '''''{{lang|es|Apertura}}''''' {{IPA-es|apeɾˈtuɾa|}} and '''''{{lang|es|Clausura}}''''' {{IPA-es|klawˈsuɾa|}} tournaments is a split [[Season (sports)|season]] format for [[sports league]]s. It is a relatively recent innovation for many [[Latin America]]n [[soccer|football]] [[sports league|leagues]] in which the traditional [[association football]] season from August to May is divided in two sections per [[season (sports)|season]], each with its own [[champion]]. ''{{lang|es|Apertura}}'' and ''{{lang|es|Clausura}}'' are the [[Spanish language|Spanish]] words for "opening" and "closing". In French-speaking [[Ligue Haïtienne|Haiti]], these are known as the ''{{lang|fr|Ouverture}}'' and the ''{{lang|fr|Fermeture}}'', while in English-speaking [[Premier League of Belize|Belize]], they are respectively the ''Opening'' and ''Closing'' seasons. The [[North American Soccer League]] (NASL) adopted a split season in [[2013 North American Soccer League season|2013]]; the season is divided into a ''Spring Championship'' and ''Fall Championship''. == Latin America == The ''{{lang|es|Apertura}}'' is held in the first half of the calendar year in [[Categoría Primera A|Colombia]], [[Ligue Haïtienne|Haiti]] and [[Paraguayan Primera División|Paraguay]] while it is held in the second half of the calendar year in Argentina, [[Liga de Fútbol Profesional Boliviano|Bolivia]], [[Chilean Primera División|Chile]], [[Costa Rican Primera División|Costa Rica]], [[Salvadoran Primera División|El Salvador]], [[Liga Nacional de Fútbol de Guatemala|Guatemala]], [[Liga Nacional de Fútbol Profesional de Honduras|Honduras]], [[Liga MX|Mexico]], [[Nicaraguan Primera División|Nicaragua]] and [[Venezuelan Primera División|Venezuela]]. The words ''{{lang|es|Apertura}}'' and ''{{lang|es|Clausura}}'' are used in most Latin American countries. Some, however, use different terminology: * Argentina: Starting in 2012–13, ''{{lang|es|Inicial}}'' and ''{{lang|es|Final}}'' (Spanish for "initial" and "final") * Colombia: ''{{lang|es|Apertura}}'' and ''{{lang|es|Finalización}}'' * Costa Rica: ''{{lang|es|Invierno}}'' and ''{{lang|es|Verano}}'' (Spanish for "winter" and "summer") In most leagues, each tournament constitutes a national championship in itself. On the other hand, in the leagues of Nicaragua, Peru, Uruguay and Venezuela, the winners of the ''{{lang|es|Apertura}}'' and ''{{lang|es|Clausura}}'' play each other in a playoff for the season title, or there is a final stage where teams qualify based on placements in the ''{{lang|es|Apertura}}'' and ''{{lang|es|Clausura}}''. Thus, two championship titles are awarded per year in the first group of leagues, and only one in the second. In Mexico and [[Superliga Colombiana|Colombia]], for instance, the winners of each tournament play each other at the beginning of the following season for another title, but this is a rather minor season curtain-raiser, akin to national [[Super Cup]]s in [[UEFA|European]] leagues. Some ''{{lang|es|Apertura}}'' and ''{{lang|es|Clausura}}'' tournaments also have second stages to decide the winner. In leagues with 12 or fewer teams, each ''{{lang|es|Apertura}}'' and ''{{lang|es|Clausura}}'' has a double round-robin format, as a means to fill in the gaps caused by the lack of elimination cup competitions as in most European countries. In leagues with 16 or more teams, each tournament has a single round-robin format. Relegations, if any, are done on an [[aggregate score|aggregate]] basis; usually the combined table for both tournaments determine relegation placements. In some leagues, the average points over the previous two or three seasons are used to determine relegation. Peru abolished its ''{{lang|es|Apertura}}'' and ''{{lang|es|Clausura}}'' format after the 2008 season but brought it back for the 2014 season. Ecuador adopted the ''{{lang|es|Apertura}}'' and ''{{lang|es|Clausura}}'' in 2005 featuring two champions in the season, however, its subsequent tournaments renamed the ''{{lang|es|Apertura}}'' and ''{{lang|es|Clausura}}'' as first and second stages, respectively, with the top placed teams advancing to a third stage to determine the champion and international qualification. Starting in 2009, the Ecuadorian championships were decided by a final between stage or group winners, maintaining the half-year tournament format. [[Argentine Football Association]] (AFA) president [[Julio Grondona]] proposed in December 2008 the return to a single championship per season format,{{cite web |url=http://www.ambitoweb.com/noticia.asp?id=434871&seccion=Deportes&fecha=25/12/2008 |title=Grondona reconoció que quiere volver a los 'torneos largos' |publisher=Ambitoweb.com |date=November 21, 2007 |accessdate=April 13, 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090123134747/http://www.ambitoweb.com/noticia.asp?id=434871&seccion=Deportes&fecha=25%2F12%2F2008 |archivedate=January 23, 2009 |deadurl=no }} and at the conclusion of the [[2014 Argentine Primera División|2014 ''{{lang|es|Primera|nocat=y}}'' season]] this happened, with the [[2015 Argentine Primera División|2015 season]] taking a European style year long season from February to December. The AFA later decided to change its season to one spanning two calendar years; as such, the [[2016 Argentine Primera División|2016 season]] is an abbreviated tournament held from February to May, followed by an August-to-June season from 2016–17 forward. == Belize == The [[Premier League of Belize]], created in 2012 by the merger of two rival top-level leagues, began a split season in 2012–13. The Opening Season takes place in the second half of the calendar year, with the Closing Season following in the first half of the next calendar year. Like most Latin American leagues, it crowns two separate champions in each season. However, its format is significantly different from that of most other leagues, being more similar to the system used by [[Major League Soccer]] in the United States and Canada. In the first split season (2012–13), the league's 12 teams were divided into two six-team zones. During the first half of the season, every team played a double round-robin within its zone, plus single games against four teams from the opposite zone, resulting in a 14-game schedule. The top two teams from each zone qualified for a playoff round, with the top team from each zone matched against the second-place team from the other zone in the two-legged semifinals. The semifinal winners advanced to a two-legged final. In the second half of the season, only eight of the initial 12 teams competed; all teams played a double round-robin in that half of the season, followed by a four-team knockout playoff (again two-legged throughout). The number of teams participating in the top flight dropped to seven for the 2013–14 season. Each half of that season will have the same format as the 2013 Closing Season. == Brazil == The [[Campeonato Brasileiro Série A|Brazilian national league]] is a notable tournament in Latin America not to split the season into two parts, using a single-season double round-robin format to decide the champions, similar to those in European leagues, though played between May and December. Brazilian clubs also participate in the [[Brazilian Football State Championship|state leagues]] from January to April, some of which do feature a split season format. Brazil also has, unlike most Latin American nations, a [[Copa do Brasil|national cup]]. == Japan and South Korea == For most of its history (except in 1996) the [[J. League]] in [[Japan]] had a similar system for its [[J1 League|first division]], although it was called 1st Stage and 2nd Stage. The seasons became unified in 2005, partially to avoid conflicts with the [[Emperor's Cup]]. It briefly resumed the same format for 2015 and 2016 seasons. The [[K-League]] of [[South Korea]] also had the same system in 1984, 1986, 1995, 2004, 2005, and 2006. In 2007, it again became unified because of confusion among fans. == United States == The NASL adopted a split-season format in 2013, divided into Spring and Fall Championships. Following the traditional standard for soccer in the United States and Canada, the season is entirely contained within a calendar year. It follows a format more similar to that of Nicaragua, Peru, Uruguay and Venezuela — each part of the season is conducted in a double round-robin format, with the winner of each part of the season advancing to a championship final known as the [[Soccer Bowl]]. == Belgium == In Belgium a large reform of the [[Belgian football league system]] was performed in 2016, which reduced the number of professional teams to 24, with only 8 teams remaining at the second level, called [[Belgian First Division B]]. From the [[2016–17 Belgian First Division B|2016–17 season]], the 8 teams will play two tournaments, with the winners of both tournaments playing a two-legged playoff to determine the overall champion. ==''{{lang|es|Apertura}}'' and ''{{lang|es|Clausura}}'' by country== All the following leagues are their country's top national division (Div 1) unless otherwise indicated. {| class="wikitable" |- ! Country ! League ! Champions ! Calendar ! Seasons |- | {{ARG}} | {{lang|es|[[Argentine Primera División|Primera División]]}} | Both (Since 1991–92) | European (August – June) | 1990–91 – 2014 |- | {{BEL}} | [[Belgian First Division B|First Division B]] (Div 2) | One | European (August – May) | 2016–17 – present |- | {{BLZ}} | [[Premier League of Belize|Premier League]] | Both (Since 2012–13) | European (August – May) | 2012–13 – present |- | {{BOL}} | {{lang|es|[[Liga de Fútbol Profesional Boliviano|Liga de Fútbol Profesional]]}} | Both (Since 2003) | European (August – May) | 1991 – present |- | {{CHI}} | {{lang|es|[[Chilean Primera División|Primera División]]}} | Both | European (July – June)
American (January – December) | 2013–14 – present
2002 – 2009, 2011 – 2012In 2010, only one championship was held due to [[2010 Chilean earthquake|the devastating earthquake]] that struck Chile that year. The country changed from the American to the European calendar beginning in 2013–14. To manage this change, the 2013 season consisted of only one championship, which the league called ''{{lang|es|Transición}}'' ("Transition"). |- | {{COL}} | {{lang|es|[[Categoría Primera A|Primera A]]}} | Both | American (February – December) | 2002 – present |- | {{CRC}} | {{lang|es|[[Costa Rican Primera División|Primera División]]}} | Both | European (August – May) | 2007–08 – present |- | {{ECU}} | {{lang|es|[[Ecuadorian Serie A|Serie A]]}} | Both | American (February – December) | 2005 |- | {{SLV}} | {{lang|es|[[Salvadoran Primera División|Primera División]]}} | Both | European (August – June) | 1998–99 – present |- | {{GUA}} | {{lang|es|[[Liga Nacional de Fútbol de Guatemala|Liga Nacional de Fútbol]]}} | Both | European (July – May) | 1999–00 – present |- | {{GUY}} | [[GFF Elite League|Elite League]] | One | European (September – June) | 2015–16 – present |- | {{HTI}} | {{lang|fr|[[Ligue Haïtienne]]}} | Both (Since 2002, except in 2005–06) | American (April – November) | 2002, 2003, 2004–05, 2007 – presentHaiti adopted the two-stage season in 2002. In 2004, it changed its season to align with the European football calendar, conducting the ''{{lang|fr|Ouverture}}'' in 2004 and the ''{{lang|fr|Fermeture}}'' in 2005. The 2005–06 season saw only one championship contested. In 2007, the league returned to the American calendar and a two-stage season. |- | {{HON}} | {{lang|es|[[Liga Nacional de Fútbol Profesional de Honduras|Liga Nacional de Fútbol]]}} | Both (Since 1997–98) | European (August – May) | 1997–98 – present |- |rowspan="2"| {{JPN}} | [[J1 League]] | One | American (March – November) | 1993 – 1995, 1997 – 2005, 2015 – 2016 |- | [[Japan Football League]] (Div 4) | One | American (March – November) | 2014 – present |- | {{MEX}} | {{lang|es|[[Liga MX]]}} | Both | European (July – May) | 1996–97 – present |- | {{NCA}} | {{lang|es|[[Nicaraguan Primera División|Primera División]]}} | One | European | |- | {{PAN}} | {{lang|es|[[Liga Panameña de Fútbol|Liga de Fútbol]]}} | Both (Since 2007) | European (July – May) | 2001 – present |- | {{PAR}} | {{lang|es|[[Paraguayan Primera División|Primera División]]}} | Both (Since 2007) | American (February – December) | 1996 – present |- | {{PER}} | {{lang|es|[[Peruvian Primera División|Primera División]]}} | One | American (February – November) | 1997–2008, 2014 – present |- | {{KOR}} | [[K League Classic]] | One | American (March – November) | 1984, 1986, 1995, 2004, 2005, 2006 |- | {{URU}} | {{lang|es|[[Uruguayan Primera División|Primera División]]}} | One | European (August – June) | 1994 – present |- | {{USA}} | [[North American Soccer League|NASL]] (unsanctioned) | One | American (April – November) | 2013 – present |- | {{VEN}} | {{lang|es|[[Venezuelan Primera División|Primera División]]}} | One | American (January – December) | 1996–97 – present |} ==Other sports== In baseball, the [[Double-A (baseball)|Double-A]] [[Southern League (baseball)|Southern]] and [[Texas League]]s in the [[United States]] both use a similar system, dividing the March–October regular season in half, with records being cleared mid-season, and the top teams mid-season and at the end of the season clinching spots in the playoff for the league [[pennant (sports)|pennant]] (the remainder of playoff slots being filled by [[wildcard (sport)|wild cards]]). This system is used in some Single-A leagues, as well. The March–September [[Chinese Professional Baseball League]] and winter [[Mexican Pacific League]] also follow the same structure, using a team's win record in each stage to determine which advance to the playoffs. Japan's [[Pacific League]] had a split season format from 1973 to 1982, with a mini-playoff between the two winners to determine the league's champion. While [[Little League Baseball]] does not mandate any specific scheduling format to be used by local leagues, it recommends dividing the regular season in half and having the first-half winner play against the second-half winner at the end of the season for the championship.{{cite web |url=http://www.littleleague.org/leagueofficers/Tips_Successful_League/2013-2014/Spring-SchedulingGamesPractices.htm |title=Spring: Scheduling Games/Practices |accessdate=2015-03-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150302001834/http://www.littleleague.org/leagueofficers/Tips_Successful_League/2013-2014/Spring-SchedulingGamesPractices.htm |archivedate=2015-03-02 |df= }} The [[Philippine Basketball Association]] also conducts a split season similar in many ways to the ''{{lang|es|Apertura}}'' and ''{{lang|es|Clausura}}''. All [[League of Legends]] leagues operate on a split-season system, with one split in the spring and one in the summer. The fall is reserved for each league's playoffs and the [[League of Legends World Championship]]. Qualification to the World Championship is decided through two avenues: winning the second split of the season, or, for the five biggest leagues, through a system that awards points based on a team's performance in each of the splits. Unlike most other split-season formats, the summer split is more important than the spring split; coming second in the summer split is worth as many points as winning the spring split. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Apertura And Clausura}} [[Category:Association football terminology]]

(14 May 1994) }} '''Austria''' is a third tier [[rugby union]] playing nation. They began playing international rugby in the early 1990s. Thus far, Austria has not made an appearance at any of the World Cups. ==History== Austria played their first official international on May 3, 1992 against [[Hungary national rugby union team|Hungary]], losing 23 points to nine. Austria had another fixture against Hungary that year, it was the first home game, which they lost 5:3, as well as two games against [[Slovenia national rugby union team|Slovenia]]. Austria's first win came against Slovenia 21.11.1992, winning 9:5. Austria played nations such as [[Croatia national rugby union team|Croatia]] and [[Ukraine national rugby union team|Ukraine]] as well as regulars Slovenia. From 1996 on Austria began winning more games, and only lost a few sporadic matches in the late 1990s, as they were now beating the European sides that had beaten them in the early 1990s. During the 2000s Austria were now playing a larger variety of nations. After not winning one game in 2002, Austria went on to win every fixture in 2004, creating an undefeated streak which was broken by [[Denmark national rugby union team|Denmark]] in 2005. ==2014 Squad== '''Squad to 2014 European Nations Cup - Division 2C.'''http://www.rugbyworldcup.com/home/matches/match=13800/index.html {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140221202823/http://www.rugbyworldcup.com/home/matches/match%3D13800/index.html |date=2014-02-21 }} {{Col-begin||width=50em}} {{Col-2}} *Maximillian Müller *Milad Farkhondeh-Fal (C) *Omar El Agrebi *Max Kinsky *Mathias Hemetsberger *Johannes Dachler *Stefan Asboth *Stefan Psota *Michael Kerschbaumer *Max Navas *Martin Leidl *Fabian Weidinger *David Barry *Stefan Reiseneder *Lukas Dobner *Mushegh Aslanyan *Maximillian Freydell *Jakob Liska *Michael Oberhauser *Stefan Pauser *Patrick Panek *Jakob Leissing *Gordon Chiu *Philipp Weidman {{Col-end}} ==Record== {| class="wikitable sortable" style="border:1px solid #CCCCCC" |- !align="left" width="175" bgcolor="#CCCCCC" |Against !align="center" width="75" bgcolor="#CCCCCC" |Played !align="center" width="75" bgcolor="#CCCCCC" |Won !align="center" width="75" bgcolor="#CCCCCC" |Lost !align="center" width="75" bgcolor="#CCCCCC" |Drawn !align="center" width="75" bgcolor="#CCCCCC" |Win percentage |- style="text-align:center; {{Use American English|date=January 2018}} {{Use mdy dates|date=January 2018}} {{Infobox award | name = Best Sports Movie ESPY Award | current_awards = | image = | imagesize = | alt = | caption = | description = best sports film | presenter = ESPN | country = | location = Los Angeles (2011) | year = 2002 | year2 = 2011 | holder = ''[[The Fighter]]'' (USA) | website = {{URL|http://www.espn.co.uk/espys/}} }} The '''Best Sports Movie ESPY Award''' was an annual award honoring the achievements of an individual from the world of [[Sports film|sports film making]]. It was first awarded as part of the [[ESPY Award]]s in 2002, and was discontinued nine years later. The Best Sports Movie ESPY Award trophy, designed by sculptor [[Lawrence Nowlan]],{{cite news|url=http://www.timesargus.com/article/20130802/NEWS03/708029923/0/FEATURES10|title=Sculptor commissioned to complete Joe Frazier statue has died|last=Avard|first=Christian|date=August 2, 2013|work=[[Barre Montpelier Times Argus]]|access-date=January 21, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140221231935/http://www.timesargus.com/article/20130802/NEWS03/708029923/0/FEATURES10|archive-date=February 21, 2014|dead-url=yes}} was bestowed annually to the sports film adjudged to be the best in a given [[calendar year]].{{cite book|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=tfTXAQAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=American+Sports:+A+History+of+Icons,+Idols+and+Ideas&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi1jbbW4-3YAhWkK8AKHWosCrIQ6AEIJzAA#v=onepage&q=ESPY&f=false|title=American Sports: A History of Icons, Idols and Ideas|last=R. Nelson|first=Murry|publisher=[[ABC-CLIO]]|year=2013|isbn=0-313-39753-8|location=[[Santa Barbara, California]]|pages=399–401|accessdate=June 24, 2015|df=mdy-all}} From 2004 onward, the winner was chosen by online voting through choices selected by the ESPN Select Nominating Committee.{{cite web|url=http://www.espn.com/espy2004/s/2004/0421/1786981.html|title=The 2004 ESPY Awards – Fans to decide all 2004 ESPY Award winners|publisher=[[ESPN]]|accessdate=23 January 2018|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180123190648/http://www.espn.com/espy2004/s/2004/0421/1786981.html|archivedate=January 23, 2018|deadurl=no}} Before that, determination of the winners was made by an panel of experts.{{cite web|url=http://www.espn.com/espy/features/01083044.html|title=Committee is newly found|date=February 3, 1999|publisher=ESPN|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180123190739/http://www.espn.com/espy/features/01083044.html|archive-date=January 23, 2018|dead-url=no|accessdate=23 January 2018}} Through the 2001 iteration of the ESPY Awards, ceremonies were conducted in February of each year to honor achievements over the previous calendar year; awards presented thereafter are conferred in July and reflect performance from the June previous.{{efn|Because of the [[ESPY Awards#Timing|rescheduling]] of the ESPY Awards ceremony, the award presented in 2002 was given in consideration of performance betwixt February 2001 and June 2002.}}{{cite press release|title=New categories unveiled for The 2002 ESPY Awards|date=2002|publisher=ESPN|url=http://www.espn.com/espy2002/s/awardcategories.html|access-date=December 20, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171222052554/http://www.espn.com/espy2002/s/awardcategories.html|archivedate=December 22, 2017|df=mdy-all}} The inaugural winner of the Best Sports Movie ESPY Award in 2002 was the [[baseball]] themed film [[The Rookie (2002 film)|''The Rookie'']] released the same year. It is based on the true story of [[Jim Morris]]' minor but notable [[Major League Baseball]] career. Films that predominantly feature [[American football]] have received the award more than any other sport, with three wins and six further nominations, followed by baseball and [[basketball]] with two victories apiece, and were nominated twice. [[John Lee Hancock]] is the director who holds more victories than any one else, one for ''The Rookie,'' and a second for [[The Blind Side (film)|''The Blind Side'']] (2010). The two sports with the most nominations that did not win the award are [[golf]] and [[horse racing]], with three each. The final winner of the Best Sports Movie ESPY Award in 2011 was the Boxing film ''[[The Fighter]]'', which centers on the lives of former professional boxers [[Micky Ward]] and [[Dicky Eklund]], and the issues they are confronted with in both their personal and professional lives.{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2011/feb/02/the-fighter-movie-micky-ward|title=The Fighter tells the story of the real-life Rocky|last=Rose|first=Steve|date=February 2, 2011|work=[[The Guardian]]|access-date=January 5, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180105233709/https://www.theguardian.com/film/2011/feb/02/the-fighter-movie-micky-ward|archive-date=January 5, 2018|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}} ==List of winners== [[File:MJK32962 Gurinder Chadha (Viceroy's House, Berlinale 2017).jpg|thumb|right|upright|[[Gurinder Chadha]]'s film ''[[Bend It Like Beckham]]'' was the only soccer film to win the award in 2003.]] [[File:David O. Russell avp 2014.jpg|thumb|right|upright|In 2011, ''[[The Fighter]]'', directed by [[David O. Russell]], was the final film to be voted the winner of the award.]] {| class="sortable wikitable plainrowheaders" |- style="white-space: nowrap;" !scope="col"|Year !scope="col"|Film !scope="col"|Director !scope="col"|Sport featured !scope="col" class="unsortable"| Nominees !scope="col" class="unsortable"| Refs |- |[[2002 in sports|2002]] |''[[The Rookie (2002 film)|The Rookie]]'' |{{sortname|John Lee|Hancock}} |[[Baseball]] | align=left | ''[[61*]]'' – [[Baseball]]

page.title: Campeonato Nacional de Boxeo Playa Girón

revision.text:
The '''Campeonato Nacional de Boxeo Playa Girón''' or '''Torneo Playa Girón''' is the yearly [[Cuba]]n [[amateur boxing]] championship. A group of boxers represent each [[Provinces of Cuba|Cuban province]], with the winner in each [[weight class]] being declared the national champion. The province whose boxers obtain the best results wins the tournament as well..<ref>{{cite web|url=https://cubasi.com/sport/item/10003-playa-giron-2016-tournament-first-steps-to-tokyo-2020 |title=Playa Giron 2016 tournament: First steps to Tokyo 2020 |publisher=CubaSi |date=2016-12-24 |accessdate=2017-07-16}}</ref><ref name="havanatimes.org">{{cite web|url=http://www.havanatimes.org/?p=84114|title=Playa Giron Boxing Tourney Ends - Havana Times.org|website=www.havanatimes.org}}</ref> The first edition took place in March of 1962.<ref name="ecured.cu">{{cite web|url=https://www.ecured.cu/Campeonato_Nacional_de_Boxeo_Playa_Gir%C3%B3n|title=Campeonato Nacional de Boxeo Playa Girón - EcuRed|website=www.ecured.cu}}</ref> Currently, the tournament is held every December<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.radiosantacruz.icrt.cu/26407-the-playa-giron-tournament-a-showcase-for-boxing-talent/#.WUV4jWg1_IU|title=The Playa Girón Tournament, a Showcase for Boxing Talent – Radio Santa Cruz|website=www.radiosantacruz.icrt.cu}}</ref><ref name="havanatimes.org"/> and it is recognized by [[International Boxing Association (amateur)|AIBA]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ecured.cu/Campeonato_Nacional_de_Boxeo_Playa_Gir%C3%B3n#Reglamento|title=Campeonato Nacional de Boxeo Playa Girón - EcuRed|website=www.ecured.cu}}</ref>. ==5-time champions== The following is a list of boxers who have won the tournament 5 or more times. Boldface denotes active boxers.

1996, 1998 |- |[[Teófilo Stevenson]]|| +81 kg / +91 kg || 11 || 1972, 1973, 1974, 1976, 1978, 1979, 1980, 1981, 1982, 1984, 1986 |- |[[Adolfo Horta]]|| 54 kg / 57 kg / 60 kg || 11 || 1976, 1977, 1978,
