{{Infobox venue |stadium_name = Modern Woodmen Park |logo_image = [[File:Modern Woodmen Park.PNG|155px]] |image = [[File:Modern Woodmen Park.jpg|300px]] |location = 209 South Gaines Street
[[Davenport, Iowa|Davenport, IA]] 52802 |coordinates = {{coord|41|31|7.21|N|90|34|56.07|W|type:landmark_scale:2000|display=inline,title}} |broke_ground = November 6, 1930{{cite book |title=Baseball at Davenport's John O'Donnell Stadium|last=Rask|first=Tim|year=2004|publisher=Arcadia Publishing|location=[[Chicago]]|isbn=0-7385-3247-9|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=eTFA9XC7D4UC&pg=PA14 |accessdate=March 5, 2012}} |built = |opened = May 26, 1931{{cite book |title=Souvenir Program|publisher=Quad City River Bandits|year=2006|page=14}} |renovated = 1989, 2004 |owner = [[Davenport, Iowa|City of Davenport]] |operator = [[Quad City River Bandits|Main Street Iowa]] |surface = Grass |construction_cost = [[United States dollar|$]]185,000 (1931)
(${{formatprice|{{Inflation|US|185000|1931}}}} in {{Inflation-year|US}} dollars{{inflation-fn|US}})
$12.5 million (2004 renovation) |architect = [[Frederick G. Clausen|Clausen, Kruse & Klein]] (original)
[[Populous (company)|Populous]] (1989, 1999, 2004 renovations) |general_contractor = Tunnicliff Construction Company |former_names = Municipal Stadium (1931–1971)
John O'Donnell Stadium (1971–2007) |tenants = [[Quad Cities River Bandits]] ([[Midwest League|MWL]]) (1931–present)
'''Seating Capacity''': 4,024{{cite book|author=Quad City River Bandits|title=Souvenir Program|year=2006|page=42}}
'''Dimensions''': Left field: 343 feet (105 m), Left Center Field: 383 feet, Center field: 400 feet (122 m), Right Center Field: 370 feet, Right field: 318 feet (97 m) }} '''Modern Woodmen Park''' (known previously as John O'Donnell Stadium and Municipal Stadium), is a [[minor league baseball]] venue located in [[Davenport, Iowa]], [[United States]]. It is home to the [[Quad Cities River Bandits]], a Class-A affiliate of the [[Houston Astros]]. Located on the banks of the [[Mississippi River]], in the shadow of the [[Rock Island Centennial Bridge|Centennial Bridge]], home run balls to right field often land in the river. [[File:Modern Woodmen Ferris Wheel.JPG|thumb|left|Modern Woodmen Park, Ferris Wheel, 2014]] ==Ball park history== As night games became more necessary, Davenport teams were playing at the Mississippi Valley Fairgrounds, without lights. The city of Davenport realized a lighted stadium, downtown, on the riverfront, would be ideal. Proposed by the Davenport Levee Commission, '''Municipal Stadium''' opened May 26, 1931 within [[LeClaire Park]]. The ballpark was built at a cost of $185,000. The first night game was June 4, 1931.{{cite web |url=http://www.cityofdavenportiowa.com/eGov/apps/document/center.egov?view=item;id=1371 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2016-02-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304160042/http://www.cityofdavenportiowa.com/eGov/apps/document/center.egov?view=item;id=1371 |archivedate=2016-03-04 |df= }} {{cite web|url=http://qctimes.com/sports/municipal-pride-john-o-donnell-stadium-turns/article_669242c4-f59a-5e62-9723-4267a2ed2629.html|title=Municipal pride John O'Donnell Stadium turns 75|first=Steve|last=Batterson|website=Qctimes.com|accessdate=14 December 2017}} Expansions in the 1940s and in 1962 brought capacity up to 6,200 and 8,500 respectively.{{cite web |title=Davenport's Modern Woodmen Park|first=Joe|last=Dinda|url=http://mwlguide.com/cities/davenport/park.html|work=MWL Guide|accessdate=March 4, 2014}} It is one of the oldest ballparks still in use in all of the minor leagues, although it underwent a major renovation before the 1989 season, lowering the seating capacity to 5,200 and before the 2004 season that brought the ballpark up to modern professional baseball standards and a [[seating capacity]] of 4,024. on May 27, 1971 the stadium was renamed '''John O'Donnell Stadium''' in honor of the longtime sports editor of the [[Quad-City Times|Davenport ''Times-Democrat'']], shortly following his death. John O'Donnell Stadium was renamed Modern Woodmen Park on December 12, 2007, after [[Rock Island, Illinois|Rock Island]]-based [[Modern Woodmen of America]] purchased the [[naming rights]] to the facility. O'Donnell's name remains on the ballpark's press box.{{cite news |title=JOD Has a New Name|first=Steve|last=Batterson|url=http://www.qctimes.com/articles/2007/12/13/news/local/doc476026a7d14e8297642559.txt|newspaper=[[Quad-City Times]]|date=December 13, 2007|accessdate=December 13, 2007}} ==Football tenants== For many years, Modern Woodmen Park played host to [[American football|football]] games in the fall. Both [[Assumption High School (Davenport, Iowa)|Assumption High School]] (a private Catholic high school in Davenport) and [[Saint Ambrose University|Saint Ambrose College]] called the field home until 1987, when both schools began playing at Brady Street Stadium. The football bleachers and press box along left field were removed in 1989. [[File:FEMA - 1479 - Photograph by Anita Westervelt taken on 05-05-2001 in Iowa.jpg|thumb|left|John O'Donnell Stadium, 05-05-2001]] ==2000's-present renovations== Renovations done before the 2004 season included a nine-foot-high berm that provided a lawn seating area for fans. The berm also acted as a flood wall around the entire stadium.{{cite news |title=Flood Has Little Effect on JOD|first=Steve|last=Batterson|url=http://qctimes.com/sports/baseball/professional/minor/midwest-league/flood-has-little-effect-on-jod/article_e3ef1f3b-1f06-5155-ab95-2b05589a2ced.html|newspaper=[[Quad-City Times]]|date=June 19, 2004|accessdate=June 4, 2014}} Until that point, the facility had no flood protection from Mississippi River flooding, which caused the team to play home games at other parks during river floods. During the [[Great Flood of 1993]], photos of water creeping across the playing field at the ballpark made national publications and became somewhat of a symbol of the flood. After the 2007 season, new owners Dave Heller and Bob Herrfeldt of Main Street Baseball came in and reinvigorated both the ballpark and the franchise. They sold naming rights to Modern Woodmen in a record 20-year deal, changed the name of the franchise back to "River Bandits," and made numerous improvements to the ballpark. In 2008, the club added a hot tub deck in right field, as well as a "[[tiki culture|tiki]] village," featuring three tiki bars, a covered tiki lounge, and a king-sized tiki bed beyond the right field wall.{{cite news |title=River Bandits Blast Past Peoria|first=Steve|last=Batterson|url=http://qctimes.com/sports/baseball/river-bandits-blast-past-peoria/article_a4ecc1ae-7ef8-5f5c-863a-c813f1458e74.html|newspaper=[[Quad-City Times]]|date=May 19, 2008|accessdate=June 4, 2014}}{{cite news |title=Bandits Fall in Extra Innings at Home|first=Steve|last=Batterson|url=http://qctimes.com/sports/baseball/bandits-fall-in-extra-innings-at-home/article_f7e41189-9573-5a51-acba-68718d121c59.html|newspaper=[[Quad-City Times]]|date=May 28, 2008|accessdate=June 4, 2014}} They also excavated a gravel area along the left-field foul line and planted field corn; by mid-season the corn grows high enough so that the home-team players are introduced at the beginning of the game and come running out of the corn field, just like in the movie ''[[Field of Dreams]]''.{{cite news |title=River Bandits Keep Flood Waters Out, Put Corn In|first=Steve|last=Batterson|url=http://qctimes.com/sports/baseball/river-bandits-keep-flood-waters-out-put-corn-in/article_20896158-1ef5-5b06-9cb8-31b875bd3b65.html|newspaper=[[Quad-City Times]]|date=April 23, 2008|accessdate=June 4, 2014}} [[File:Modern Woodmen Park 2.jpg|left|300px|thumb|Modern Woodmen Park from the Centennial Bridge]] For 2009, Main Street Baseball continued to make improvements, adding a new {{convert|80|ft|m|adj=mid|-long}}, {{convert|6|ft|m|adj=mid|-tall}} high-definition ribbon board along the right field fence and installing four new concourse-level "loge boxes" to accommodate small groups of people.{{cite news |title=River Bandits to Install Video Ribbon Board in Outfield|first=Steve|last=Batterson|url=http://qctimes.com/sports/baseball/river-bandits-to-install-video-ribbon-board-in-outfield/article_1742252b-1def-5bda-8226-a8b8bf5bdf85.html|newspaper=[[Quad-City Times]]|date=November 18, 2008|accessdate=June 4, 2014}} Prior to the 2010 season, the City of Davenport and Main Street Baseball replaced the entire field, to facilitate proper drainage and minimize rain outs. Other new changes for 2010 included a new concession stand on the Picnic Plaza level and a new group terrace next to the Tiki Village beyond the right-center field fence. In 2014, the facility received another noteworthy addition, as a 110-foot [[Ferris wheel]] was constructed just beyond the left field wall.{{cite news |title=Ballpark Ferris Wheel Takes Its First Riders for a Spin|first=Bill|last=Wundram|url=http://qctimes.com/news/opinion/editorial/columnists/bill-wundram/ballpark-ferris-wheel-takes-its-first-riders-for-a-spin/article_ebd8f518-ba99-597a-8138-e5ef52357a5d.html|newspaper=[[Quad-City Times]]|date=May 21, 2014|accessdate=June 4, 2014}} In 2017, the park added a double-decker [[carousel]] purchased from [[Pier 39]] in [[San Francisco]].{{cite web |url=http://www.milb.com/content/page.jsp?ymd=20170906&content_id=252849928&fext=.jsp&sid=t565&vkey= |title=Double-Decker Carousel |accessdate=April 10, 2018}} [[File:Joshua Hill (baseball player).jpg|thumb|left|Joshua Hill pitch, Centennial Bridge from the Ballpark 2003]] ==Ballpark Awards== For both the 2008 and 2009 seasons, Modern Woodmen Park won the "Best Ballpark Improvement" Award from Ballparkdigest.com, the industry's leading publication.{{cite web |title=Awards & Honors|url=http://www.milb.com/content/page.jsp?sid=t565&ymd=20091008&content_id=7396404&vkey=team4|publisher=Minor League Baseball|date=October 8, 2009|accessdate=June 4, 2014}} In 2013, the park was voted as the top minor-league ballpark in the United States in a [[USA Today]] and [[10best.com]] reader poll. Modern Woodmen Park beat second place Louisville Slugger Field by around 2,000 votes.{{cite web|title=Best Minor League Park Winners: 2013 10Best Reader's Choice Travel Awards|url=http://www.10best.com/awards/travel/best-minor-league-ballpark/|work=10best|accessdate=August 14, 2013}}{{cite news |title=Davenport's Ballpark Is Chosen As the Nation's Best|first=Steve|last=Batterson|url=http://qctimes.com/sports/baseball/professional/minor/davenport-s-ballpark-is-chosen-as-the-nation-s-best/article_0695502e-e9c6-5b67-93b9-4af99772a914.html|newspaper=[[Quad-City Times]]|date=August 14, 2013|accessdate=August 14, 2013}} ==Notable events== The River Bandits (then known as the Swing of the Quad Cities) defeated the [[Burlington Bees]], 1–0, in the first game at the renovated Modern Woodmen Park on April 29, 2004.{{cite news |title=Fans Pack Newly Renovated Facility as Swing Win 1-0|first=Thomas|last=Geyer|url=http://qctimes.com/news/local/fans-pack-newly-renovated-facility-as-swing-win/article_cb98c410-655d-5f22-bc43-8de5d3886a13.html|newspaper=[[Quad-City Times]]|date=April 29, 2004|accessdate=June 4, 2014}} The 2006 and 2011 [[Midwest League]] All-Star Games were held at Modern Woodmen Park. Previously, the ballpark hosted Midwest League All-Star Games in 1964, 1968, 1975, 1980, 1982 and 1990, giving the facility a total of eight.{{cite news |title=Event at John O’Donnell Goes on Despite Obstacles|first=Don|last=Doxsie|url=http://qctimes.com/news/local/event-at-john-o-donnell-goes-on-despite-obstacles/article_cae549f1-b54e-5ff6-adce-47040137a49a.html|newspaper=[[Quad-City Times]]|date=June 21, 2006|accessdate=June 4, 2014}}{{cite news |title=Minors President: Q-C Scene a Thing of Beauty|first=Steve|last=Batterson|url=http://qctimes.com/sports/baseball/professional/minor/midwest-league/minors-president-q-c-scene-a-thing-of-beauty/article_8deb5a92-9a2c-11e0-a54a-001cc4c002e0.html|newspaper=[[Quad-City Times]]|date=June 21, 2011|accessdate=June 4, 2014}} In the summer of 2007, portions of the critically acclaimed film ''[[Sugar (2008 film)|Sugar]]'' was shot at the park. This included 800–1,000 people a night showing up to be extras. The movie follows the path of a young man from the impoverished Dominican Republic as he chases dreams of baseball stardom in America.{{cite news |title=Iowa Likely to See Rise in Movie Production|first=David|last=Burke|url=http://www.qctimes.com/news/local/article_85e8fac0-2a9e-11de-a745-001cc4c03286.html|newspaper=[[Quad-City Times]]|date=April 16, 2009|accessdate=April 16, 2009}} The stadium was the site of the "Rumble on the Riverbank" [[boxing]] match on May 10, 1991. [[Michael Nunn]], a Davenport native, lost the [[International Boxing Federation|IBF]] [[middleweight]] title to [[James Toney]].{{cite web |title='Ropes' Tied by Fact or Fiction?|first=Jeff|last=Merron|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/espn/page3/story?page=merron/040305|work=[[ESPN]]|date=March 5, 2004|accessdate=June 4, 2014}} "Mississippi River Jam II" was held on June 3, 1979 featuring [[AC/DC]], [[Heart (band)|Heart]], [[UFO (band)|UFO]] [[TKO (band)|TKO]] and [[Nazareth (band)|Nazareth]].{{cite web|url=http://wncx.cbslocal.com/2013/06/03/on-this-day-in-acdc-history-june-3rd-1979/|title=On This Day In AC/DC History...June 3rd, 1979|date=3 June 2013|website=Wncx.cbslocal.com|accessdate=14 December 2017}} The facility has hosted many concerts by many artists, including: [[Johnny Cash]], [[The Beach Boys]], [[Johnny Winter]], [[Bryan Adams]], [[Def Leppard]], [[REO Speedwagon]], [[Blue Öyster Cult]], [[Eddie Money]], [[Edgar Winter Group]] and [[Lonestar]].{{cite web|url=http://www.setlist.fm/venue/john-odonnell-stadium-davenport-ia-usa-bd7f182.html|title=John O'Donnell Stadium, Davenport, IA, USA Concert Setlists|website=Setlist.fm|accessdate=14 December 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.setlist.fm/venue/municipal-stadium-davenport-ia-usa-5bd4eb3c.html|title=Municipal Stadium, Davenport, IA, USA Concert Setlists |website=Setlist.fm|accessdate=14 December 2017}} Johnny Cash played at the stadium twice, in 1974 and 1976, drawing over 10,000 each time and playing for free.{{cite web|url=http://qctimes.com/news/opinion/editorial/columnists/bill-wundram/sober-or-not-cash-took-q-c-by-storm/article_cec8892d-8413-5bbf-8bc9-50c248b33183.html|title=Sober or not, Cash took Q-C by storm|website=Qctimes.com|accessdate=14 December 2017}} On Oct. 1, 1936 an exhibition game featuring major-league players and [[Negro National League (1933–48)|Negro National League]] All Stars included [[Baseball Hall of Fame]] players [[Satchel Paige]], [[Cool Papa Bell]], [[Rogers Hornsby]] and [[Johnny Mize]] ==Media== The stadium and teams were the subject of a book. Baseball Historian Tim Rask wrote ''Baseball at Davenport's John O'Donnell Stadium'', released in 2004.{{cite web |url=https://www.arcadiapublishing.com/9780738532479/Baseball-at-Davenports-John-ODonnell-Stadium |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2016-02-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305074753/https://www.arcadiapublishing.com/9780738532479/Baseball-at-Davenports-John-ODonnell-Stadium |archivedate=2016-03-05 |df= }} ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== * [http://www.milb.com/content/page.jsp?sid=t565&ymd=20070412&content_id=206132&vkey=team1 History of Modern Woodmen Park]: * Renovations Video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7lUJi0r-uJ8 {{Midwest League Ballparks}} {{Quad Cities}} {{Houston Astros}} {{Davenport}} [[Category:Baseball venues in Iowa]] [[Category:Defunct American football venues]] [[Category:Minor league baseball venues]] [[Category:Sports venues in the Quad Cities]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Davenport, Iowa]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Davenport, Iowa]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1931]] [[Category:1931 establishments in Iowa]]

{{merge from|Chrysler Hall|date=February 2018|discuss=Talk:Chrysler Hall}} {{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Norfolk Scope | nickname = | logo_image = [[Image:Norfolk Scope logo color.jpg|150px]] | image = Norfolk Scope2.JPG | image_size = 250px | location = 201 East Brambleton Avenue
[[Norfolk, Virginia]] 23510 | broke_ground = June 6, 1968{{cite web |title=Scope Cultural and Convention Center Groundbreaking Ceremony|url=http://nrha.photoshelter.com/image/I0000ds2wSCvuW_g|publisher=Norfolk Redevelopment and Housing Authority|date=June 6, 1968|accessdate=August 12, 2013|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Iosc8TqD|archivedate=August 12, 2013}} | opened = November 12, 1971 | owner = [[Norfolk, Virginia|City of Norfolk]] | operator = [[Norfolk, Virginia|City of Norfolk]] | construction_cost = [[United States dollar|$]]35 million
(${{formatprice|{{Inflation|US|35000000|1971}}}} in {{Inflation-year|US}} dollars{{inflation-fn|US}})
$14.5 million (upgrades since 2003) | architect = [[Pier Luigi Nervi]]
Williams and Tazewell | structural engineer = Fraioli-Blum-Yesselman[http://www.columbia.edu/cu/gsapp/BT/DOMES/TIMELN/vasc/vasc.html Norfolk Dome - Timeline: Important Precedents in Stadium Design] | general_contractor = Daniel Construction Co.{{cite news |title=Norfolk's Coliseum to Be Ready November 1|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1298&dat=19701230&id=8tJNAAAAIBAJ&sjid=XooDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5064,192852|newspaper=[[The Free Lance-Star]]|location=Fredericksburg|date=December 30, 1970|accessdate=February 20, 2012}} | former_names = | tenants = [[Virginia Squires]] ([[American Basketball Association|ABA]]) (1971–1976)
[[Old Dominion Monarchs]] ([[NCAA]]) (full time 1977–1990, part time 1971–2002)
[[Hampton Roads Admirals]] (ECHL) (1989–2000)
[[Norfolk Nighthawks]] ([[AF2]]) (2000–2003)
[[Norfolk Admirals (AHL)|Norfolk Admirals]] ([[American Hockey League|AHL]]) (2000–2015)
[[Norfolk SharX]] ([[Major Indoor Soccer League (2008–2014)|MISL]]) (2011–2012)
[[Norfolk Admirals (ECHL)|Norfolk Admirals]] ([[ECHL]]) (2015–present) | seating_capacity = [[Ice hockey]]: 8,701
[[Basketball]]: 10,253
[[Concerts]]: 13,800 }} '''Norfolk Scope''' is a multi-function complex in [[Norfolk, Virginia]], comprising an 11,000-person [[arena]], a 2,500-person theater known as [[Chrysler Hall]], a 10,000 square foot-exhibition hall and a 600-car parking garage. The arena was designed by Italian architect/engineer [[Pier Luigi Nervi]] in conjunction with the (now defunct) local firm Williams and Tazewell, which designed the entire complex. Nervi's design for the arena's reinforced concrete dome derived from the [[PalaLottomatica]] and the much smaller [[Palazzetto dello Sport]], which were built in the 1950s for the [[1960 Summer Olympics]] in [[Rome]]. Construction on Scope began in June 1968 at the northern perimeter of Norfolk's downtown and was completed in 1971 at a cost of [[United States dollar|$]]35 million. Federal funds covered $23 million of the cost, and when it opened formally on November 12, 1971, the structure was the second-largest public complex in Virginia, behind only the Pentagon.{{cite news |title=Architect Left His Mark on Many Iconic Norfolk Structures|first=Philip|last=Walzer|url=http://hamptonroads.com/2011/07/architect-left-his-mark-many-iconic-norfolk-structures|newspaper=[[The Virginian-Pilot]]|location=Norfolk|date=July 25, 2011|accessdate=July 26, 2011}} Featuring the [[List of world's largest domes|world's largest reinforced thinshell concrete dome]] (though eclipsed by the Seattle [[Kingdome|Seattle Kingdome]] from 1972 to 2000), Scope won the Virginia Society of the American Institute of Architects ''Test of Time'' award in 2003.{{cite news |title=Norfolk's Scope Wins 'Time-Tested' Architecture Prize|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/dailypress/access/443006861.html?dids=443006861:443006861&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Nov+09%2C+2003&author=The+Virginian-Pilot&pub=Daily+Press&desc=NORFOLK'S+SCOPE+WINS+'TIME-TESTED'+ARCHITECTURE+PRIZE&pqatl=google|newspaper=[[Daily Press (Virginia)|Daily Press]]|location=Newport News|date=November 9, 2003|accessdate=July 30, 2011}} Wes Lewis, director of [[Old Dominion University]]'s civil engineering technology program, called it "a beautiful marrying of art and engineering." Noted architectural critic [[James Howard Kunstler]] described the design as looking like "yesterday's tomorrow." The name "Scope", a contraction of ''kaleidoscope'',{{cite news |title=What's in a Name? Scope Arena, Norfolk|first=Patrick|last=Wilson|url=http://hamptonroads.com/2009/03/whats-name-scope-arena-norfolk|newspaper=[[The Virginian-Pilot]]|location=Norfolk|date=March 23, 2009|accessdate=July 30, 2011}} emphasizes the venue's re-configurability. The facility logo (right), which features a multi-colored, abstracted kaleidoscope image, was designed by [[Raymond Loewy]]'s firm ''Loewy/Snaith'' of New York.{{cite web |title=Celebrate America this July with Gary Kollberg's Exhibit at the Farmington Library|url=http://farmingtonlibctart.blogspot.com/2009_07_01_archive.html|publisher=Farmington Library of Art|location=Farmington, CT|date=July 1, 2009}} ==History and design== After watching the 1960 Rome Summer Olympics on television, and seeing the [[PalaLottomatica|Palazzo]] and [[Palazzetto dello Sport]], Brad Tazewell and Jim Williams, two Norfolk architects, solicited U.S. Sen. [[A. Willis Robertson]], father of [[Pat Robertson]], to build a sports complex in Norfolk. Subsequently, President [[Lyndon B. Johnson]] asked Robertson to support federal funding for a multimillion-dollar cultural center in Colorado and Robertson said he would if Johnson would support one in Norfolk. Williams and Tazewell was subsequently commissioned; they in turn commissioned Nervi. The complex was an important part of the first phase of Norfolk's post-World War II revitalization. A large section of the city's downtown was razed, and the Scope complex was to "anchor" its northern corner, with the [[Vincent G. Kling|Vincent Kling]] designed Courthouse and Civic complex anchoring the Eastern edge of downtown. The arena is located on its 14-acre site above a raised [[plinth]], below which is located a parking garage for 640 cars. The facility includes a {{convert|65000|sqft|m2|abbr=on}} exhibit hall as well as the adjacent Chrysler Hall, a music and theater venue, home to the [[Virginia Symphony Orchestra]]. The arena's seating can be reconfigured to accommodate from 10,253 for sporting events up to 13,800 for concerts. With a concrete [[monolithic dome|monolithic]] dome measuring 440 ft (134 m) in diameter and a height of 110 ft (33.5 m), the dome was, at the time of its construction, the largest of its kind in the world — and was displaced as the record holder after the construction of the Seattle [[Kingdome]]. After the demolition of the larger [[Kingdome]] in 2000, Scope reclaimed the title as having the [[List of world's largest domes|world's largest reinforced thin-shell concrete dome]]. Supported by 24 [[flying buttress]]es, the arena roof encloses {{convert|85000|sqft|m2|abbr=on}}. With over 1,000 pilings, the facility was constructed 10' below the city's water table. The roof is a ribbed concrete dome, independent of seating bowl formed of sloped concrete beams supporting precast treads and risers which form the seating bowl. The perimeter of the dome roof is supported by a combination of vertical columns and inclined buttresses, which tie into a [[tension ring]] below ground. A concentric ring, approximately 7' 9" wide, is suspended from the dome, for service and lighting needs. During preparations for the first hosting of the [[Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey Circus]], a bear escaped its cage and ran across the wet paint on the floor of the unfinished Exhibition Hall below. During the first presentation in the Exhibition Hall of the Hampton Roads Automobile Show, visitors could spot bear tracks in the painted floor, between the exhibitions. (Source: ''[[The Virginian-Pilot]]'') The arena has undergone $11 million of renovations since 2003, including the replacement of a center-hung scoreboard with a matrix screen on each side with a center-hung scoreboard with LED video and matrix boards and two LED end-zone videoboards in 2008. A new glass wall has been installed, and is expected to be extended in order to expand the arena's main concourse at a cost of $3.5 million in 2014. This would result in additional restrooms and concession stands at the arena. There has been discussion about expanding the Norfolk Scope, by adding 5,000 seats and 24 luxury suites, in the near future, in order to remain competitive with neighboring venues in the southeastern and mid-Atlantic states.{{cite news |title=Here’s what digging down to expand Scope could look like. The next question is cost.|first=Eric|last=Hartley|url=https://pilotonline.com/news/government/local/here-s-what-digging-down-to-expand-scope-could-look/article_c39fd995-0072-5585-a9e3-9c1fdcc5777b.html|newspaper=[[The Virginian-Pilot]]|location=Norfolk|date=November 6, 2017|accessdate=November 6, 2017}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[https://www.sevenvenues.com/venues/detail/scope-arena Norfolk Scope Official Site (Norfolk's Seven Venues)] {{s-start-collapsible|header={{S-sta|et}}}} {{Succession box | title = Host of [[Destination X (2008)|Destination X]] | years = 2008 | before = [[TNA Impact! Zone]] | after = [[TNA Impact! Zone]] }} {{end}} {{Norfolk Admirals}} {{ECHL Arenas}} {{NISL Arenas}} {{ABAteams}} {{ABAPlayoffs}} {{Norfolk, Virginia}} {{Music venues of Virginia}} {{Old Dominion Monarchs basketball navbox}} {{coord|36|51|11.79|N|76|17|12.20|W|type:landmark_scale:2000|display=title}} [[Category:1971 establishments in Virginia]] [[Category:American Basketball Association venues]] [[Category:Indoor arenas in Virginia]] [[Category:Basketball venues in Virginia]] [[Category:Indoor ice hockey venues in the United States]] [[Category:Indoor soccer venues in the United States]] [[Category:Norfolk Admirals]] [[Category:Old Dominion Monarchs and Lady Monarchs basketball]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1971]] [[Category:Sports venues in Norfolk, Virginia]] [[Category:Virginia Squires]] [[Category:Arena football venues]] [[Category:Defunct college basketball venues in the United States]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Norfolk, Virginia]] [[Category:Downtown Norfolk, Virginia]]

{{redirect|NAGA|other uses|naga (disambiguation)}} {{multiple issues| {{one source|date=January 2012}} {{primary sources|date=January 2012}} }} {{Infobox martial arts tournament | name = North American Grappling Association | current_event = | image = [[File:Naga.png|200px]] | date = Established in 1995 | locale = [[North America]]
MMA locales -
[[Massachusetts]]; [[New Jersey]] | english = | localnames = | nickname = | discipline = '''[[Submission Grappling]]''' - [[Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu]]
'''[[Full contact sport]]s''' - [[Mixed martial arts]] | competition = | type = Open Tournaments | organiser = NAGA | president = Kipp Kollar | skill = [[North American Grappling Association#Skill Levels|List of skill levels]] | weight = [[North American Grappling Association#Weight Divisions|List of weight divisions]] | first = | number = | last = | firstwinner = | mostwins = | mostrecent = }} '''The North American Grappling Association (NAGA)''' is an organization started in 1995 that holds [[Submission Grappling]] and [[Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu]] tournaments throughout [[North America]] and [[Europe]]. NAGA is the largest submission grappling association in the world with over 200,000 participants world-wide, including some of the top submission grapplers and MMA fighters in the world.{{cite web |url=http://www.nagafighter.com |title= Nagafighter.com |date= |publisher= North American Grappling Association |accessdate=13 May 2013}} NAGA grappling tournaments consist of [[keikogi|gi]] and no-gi divisions. No-Gi competitors compete under rules drafted by NAGA. Gi competitors compete under standardized [[Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu]] rules. NAGA also promotes [[Mixed martial arts|MMA]] events which they term Reality Fighting. ==Skill Levels== Competitors in NAGA competitions are broken into weight divisions and skill levels. Skill levels are further divided into a two categories, Adults/Masters/Directors/Executives, and Children/Teens. ===Adults/Masters/Directors/Executives{{clarification|date=December 2016}}=== * Novice (6 months total grappling experience) * Beginner (6 months to 2 years total grappling experience) * Intermediate (2 years to 5 years total grappling experience. BJJ blue belts are Intermediate) * Expert (5 years + total grappling experience. BJJ purple, brown, black belts are Expert) ===Children & Teens=== * Novice (6 months & under total grappling experience. Children are not allowed to do submissions) * Beginner (6 months to 1 year total grappling experience) * Intermediate (1 year to 2 years total grappling experience) * Advance (2 years to 3 years total grappling experience) * Expert (3 years + total grappling experience) Total grappling experience includes but is not limited to; wrestling experience, BJJ experience, judo experience, sambo experience, JKD experience, etc. Any training that consists of grappling is counted towards your total experience. ==Weight Divisions== ===Men's & Master's No-Gi & Gi, White Belts & Blue Belt {{Refimprove|date=March 2009}} '''Over-the-line''' is a [[Bat-and-ball games|bat-and-ball]] sport, a game related to [[baseball]] and [[softball]]. Like those games, you have the bar, pitcher, and fielders. Because a game requires only three people per team, it is considerably easier to get a good informal game going. Equipment consists of a rope (or lines marked in the sand), an "official" softball bat and a rubber softball. No ball gloves are allowed except in women's games, however golf gloves may be used when batting.Game play, however, is very different.
[[Image:Over the line court.png|thumb|A diagram of an Over-The-Line court]] The name "over-the-line" is a [[registered trademark]] of the Old Mission Beach Athletic Club (OMBAC) of [[San Diego]], [[California]], which organizes an annual tournament that is one of the city's largest summer social events. It is also known as OTL (also trademarked by OMBAC).<ref>{{cite news |last=Buckheit |first=Mary |title=Play ball ... and enjoy the sights |url=http://www.espn.com/espn/page2/story?page=buckheit/060718 |work=ESPN}}</ref> OMBAC allows other organizations to license the trademark for their own events for a nominal fee.
An over-the-line court is normally made up on a beach and comprises a triangle and an open ended rectangle marked by ropes or lines in the sand. The base ("The Line") of the triangle is {{convert|55|ft|m}} long, and the distance from the line to the opposite point ("Home") is also {{convert|55|ft|m}}. The rectangle is composed of two parallel ropes or lines that extend out indefinitely away from home starting from the two ends of The Line and at a right angle to The Line. The area between the parallel ropes and over The Line is fair territory. Everything other than the triangle and fair territory is foul territory.
[[Image:OTL01.jpg|thumb|Pitching and Batting]]
Unlike in softball, the batter and pitcher are on the same team. The batter stands at Home. The pitcher stands anywhere in front of The Line, not in the triangle. Fielders (the other team) stand behind The Line, in fair territory. The objective for the batter is get a hit which is to hit the ball into fair territory without a fielder catching it. A hit may also be made when the fielder who catches the ball crosses over the line (or the line's extension) or drops the ball in either fair or foul territory. No bases are physically run, however.
An out is made if (a) the ball is hit into your triangle, (b) a batter gets a strike (swings and completely misses), (c) the defenders catch the ball without crossing over The Line or its extensions, (d) a batter has two fouls (a foul is a ball that lands in foul territory, a pitch taken at or a balk), (e) a player bats out of order or (f) either the pitcher or batter touch but do not catch a struck ball (if the pitcher or batter catch it there is a no pitch). Unlike baseball and softball, where the foul lines are in fair territory, the ropes are in foul territory. Three outs end the half-inning, as in regular baseball and softball.
The scoring system is as follows: # The third hit in an inning scores one run and each subsequent hit scores another run and # A home run (a ball that lands past the Fielder furthest from The Line, not over, just needs to be past) without it being touched by a Fielder scores a run and the unscored hits that preceded it. The hits are then reset to zero.
== Annual tournament == [[File:OldMissionBayAquaticClub.jpg|thumb|Old Mission Beach Athletic Club sign at the Over the Line event]] Over-the-line was first played in [[Mission Beach, San Diego, California]] in the 1950s<ref>{{cite news |last=Jurjevics |first=Rosa |date=12 July 2007 |title=Their Own Little World: Mission Beach |url=http://www.sandiegoreader.com/news/2007/jul/12/their-own-little-world-mission-beach/ |newspaper=San Diego Reader}}</ref> and continues to thrive in the area. It is seen largely as a novelty game in the inland counties (and, debatably, the beach counties as well), but still persists as a physical education activity at local high schools, and most visibly in the practice of an annual tournament held on [[Mission Bay, San Diego, California|Fiesta Island]]. By far the locale's most notorious activity, the annual "OMBAC World Championship Over The Line Tournament", organized by Old Mission Beach Athletic Club, is a prominent event in San Diego's beach sports life. The tournament has a history of adult themed team names, often with variations of the sport's equipment — namely bats and balls — that are seen as explicit enough to discourage most youth attendance. Over the years, the tournament gained a reputation for its hedonistic and sexual overtones. To help emphasize the sport rather than the spectacle, OMBAC has made strides to cut back on these and some of the tournament's other, more offensive, elements. The tournament is much more than "beer, babes, and bats on the beach."
The annual World Championships now gathers more than 1200 teams from all over the world. They compete in many different divisions. The divisions are separated by age and gender. Players from 18 to 80 years of age are participating. There are men's and women's teams and the sport is taken very seriously by the players. In 1977 players got gray hairs because of the stress There is even an OTL Players Association that was established to help further the sport and hosts several additional tournaments per year.
The tournament has gained a negative stigma by many who have never attended. As the population that began the event continues to age (the tournament began in 1954), the game garners increasing acceptance from the San Diego populace and governing bodies. Because of the sport and the party atmosphere this event fosters, OMBAC once again welcomed about 60,000 spectators over the two July weekends it was held in 2011.
== References == {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.ombac.org/over-the-line/ Old Mission Beach Athletic Club's Over The Line Website] * [http://www.otlplayers.com OTL Players Social Network]

{{See also|Wanderers F.C.}} {{Infobox rugby team | teamname = Public School Wanderers | image = Public Schools Wanderers Logo.png | imagesize = 150px | union = [[Rugby Football Union]] | fullname = Public School Wanderers Rugby and Cricket Club | nickname = PSW, Wanderers | shortname = | countryflag = ENG | countryflagvar = | founded = 1940 | region = <!-- useful for Provincial and super sides--> | ground = | capacity = | chairman = | ceo = <!-- If the union/club has a Chief Executive Officer --> | president = <!-- If the union/club has a President --> | captain = | top scorer = | caps = | coach = | url = www.wix.com/lwrfc1/publicschoolwanderers/ | league = | season = | position = | pattern_la1 = | pattern_b1 = | pattern_ra1 = | pattern_so1 = | pattern_sh1 = <!-- these are for specific uploaded kit images--> | leftarm1 = | body1 = | rightarm1 = | shorts1 = | socks1 = | pattern_la2 = | pattern_b2 = | pattern_ra2 = | pattern_so2 = | pattern_sh2 = <!-- these are for specific uploaded kit images--> | leftarm2 = | body2 = | rightarm2 = | shorts2 = | socks2 = }}
The '''Public School Wanderers Club''' is a sports club in the United Kingdom that was formed in 1940 by [[Charles Burton (journalist)|Charles Burton]], a [[Fleet Street]] [[journalist]]. It was formed to provide [[cricket]] and [[rugby union|rugby]] for [[Independent school (United Kingdom)|public school]]boys during their school holidays, but with difficulties arising from [[World War II]] the Club started to provide games for [[Armed forces|servicemen]] as well. During the period of hostilities the Club provided over a thousand games of cricket and rugby for servicemen from all parts of the [[Commonwealth of Nations|British Commonwealth]].
==Founding principles==
===Ethos=== After the war the Club became open, though still by invitation only; a player is invited to become a Wanderer because they are a credit to their sport (be it cricket or rugby) and will enter into the spirit of maintaining the high standards of play and conduct achieved by generations of preceding club members.
===Colours, crest and motto=== The club colours are red (representing the morning sky), green (for the playing field) and pink (of the setting sun).
The club crest contains five [[heraldic charge|charges]], a book (representing scholarship and the schools from which the original players were drawn), the lion of [[Cambridge University RFC]], the crown of [[Oxford University RFC]], the [[Rod of Asclepius]] representing the [[United Hospitals RFC]] and an escallop which has connotations of [[pilgrimage]] in [[heraldry]]. There is also a [[Mitre|Bishop's Mitre]] for the church affiliated public schools.
The club motto is ''In concordia floreamus'' which is [[Latin]] for ''In friendship we flourish''.
==Rugby==
===History=== The rugby team play regional fixtures, celebration games, provide teams to play in developing rugby countries and engage in other rugby missionary activities. They play the 15-a-side version of the game though it is in [[Rugby sevens|7-a-side]] rugby tournaments that the Wanderers have made their reputation. Since its inception over 2000 players have represented the Wanderers in over 5,000 matches.<ref name="sundayobserver">http://www.sundayobserver.lk/2005/06/12/spo02.html</ref>
The Wanderers have played "international" fixtures against [[Belgium national rugby union team|Belgium]], [[Germany national rugby union team|Germany]], [[The Netherlands national rugby union team|The Netherlands]], [[Italy national rugby union team|Italy]], [[Kenya national rugby union team|Kenya]] and [[New Zealand national rugby union team|New Zealand]], they have also toured [[Bermuda]], Canada, [[East Africa]], [[South Africa]], [[Uruguay]], United States and most European countries. They even took over the [[British and Irish Lions|British Lions']] cancelled fixtures in [[Zimbabwe]] in 1982. They have been finalists on two occasions at the [[Middlesex Sevens]], represented England at the [[Monte Carlo Sevens]] in 1987, 1988 and winning in 1989. They were finalists at the 1988 [[Hong Kong Sevens]] and won the [[London Sevens]] as well as the 1996 [[Safari Sevens]] in [[Nairobi]], [[Kenya]].<ref name="sundayobserver" />
A notable event in the history of the Wanderers occurred in the 1988 – 89 season when it fielded a team comprising 15 internationals against a [[Bath RFC|Bath]] XV consisting of a full complement of Internationals also. Bath was the first non-invitation club to have been able to field a fully international side since [[Newport RFC]] did so in 1902.
The modern era has required the Wanderers to refocus their fixture list to reflect the realities of the modern professional rugby, taking into account the contractual obligations that players now have with their clubs. Clubs still benefit from the more relaxed games that the Wanderers offer and to use them to test players returning from injury or to give younger players the opportunity to demonstrate their talents.
Nomadic by tradition, the club continues to play representative matches and to tour developing rugby countries, true to their roots – a combination of youth and experience. Though the club has evolved to match the developments in the sport, they still measure their success not by victories but by its established tradition of playing entertaining rugby. Any club wishing to invite the Wanderers to participate in a commemorative game or tournament either at home or abroad should contact the club via its website.
===Matches, tours and tournament results===
====Seven-a-side tournaments==== {{Inc-sport}} <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wix.com/lwrfc1/publicschoolwanderers/|title=Wix.com PublicSchoolWanderers created by lwrfc1 based on Blank Website|work=Wix.com PublicSchoolWanderers created by lwrfc1 based on Blank Website}}</ref> * [[Aberayron Sevens]] - Winners * [[Amsterdam Sevens]] - Winners * [[Bridgend Sevens]] - Winners * [[Cheltenham Sevens]] - Winners * [[Cwmtawe Sevens]] - Winners * [[Glengarth Sevens]] - Winners (4 times) * [[Hawick Centenary Sevens]] - Winners * [[Harrogate Sevens]] - Winners * [[Headingly Sevens]] - Winners * [[Hong Kong Sevens]] - Finalists, 1985 * [[London Sevens]] - Winners * [[London Welsh Centenary Sevens]] - Winners * [[Lords Taverners Sevens]] - Winners * [[Melrose Sevens]] in 1975 * [[Middlesex Sevens]] - Finalists (twice), once on 27 April 1963 * [[Midland Sevens]] at Coventry – Winners 2001, beating [[Ebbw Vale RFC]] 16-6 * [[Monte Carlo Sevens]] - Winners * [[Murrayfield Sevens]] - Winners * [[Northern Sevens]] - Winners * [[Oxford Sevens]] - Winners * [[Punta Del Este Sevens]] tournament in [[Uruguay]] 1994<ref>{{cite web |url=http://02d4131.netsolhost.com/r7/02dec29.asp |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-12-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120406222027/http://02d4131.netsolhost.com/r7/02dec29.asp |archivedate=2012-04-06 |df= }}</ref> - Semi Finalists * [[Safari Sevens]] - Winners (twice), [[Colin Charvis]] Captained the side and they won the tournament in 1996, won Plate 1997, won tournament 1999 * [[Scarborough Festival]] - Winners * [[Selkirk Sevens]] - Winners, 30 August 1980

{{Infobox football club| clubname = Sandawana FC| image = Sandawana_FC_Logo.png| fullname = Sandawana Football Club| nickname = | founded = | ground = [[St. Michaels Stadium]],
[[Maputsoe]], [[Lesotho]]| capacity = 1,000| chairman = | manager = | league = [[Lesotho Premier League]]| season = 2013–14| position = 10th| }} '''Sandawana Football Club''' is a Lesotho football club based in Mpharane. It is based in the city of [[Makheka, Thaba-Tseka District]] in the region [[Thaba-Tseka District]]. The team currently plays in [[Lesotho Second Division]]. In 2014 the club was renamed from Mpharane Celtics to Sandawana. ==Stadium== Currently the team plays at the 1,000 capacity [[St. Michaels Stadium]]. ==Performance in CAF competitions== *[[Lesotho Premier League]]: 2011–2013 *[[Lesotho Second Division]]: ????–2011, 2013– ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[https://int.soccerway.com/teams/lesotho/mpharane-celtics/20002/ Soccerway] *[http://www.vflnet.com/infos/lesotho/mpharane_celtics_fc/ VFLnet] *[http://www.weltfussballarchiv.com/club-profile/lesotho/mpharane-celtics-fc/13498/ Weltfussballarchiv] {{Lesotho Premier League}} [[Category:Football clubs in Lesotho]] {{Lesotho-footyclub-stub}}

page.title: Social media coverage of the Olympics

revision.comment: Remove 1 stray access-date. ([[User:GreenC bot/Job 5|GreenC bot job #5]])
revision.text:
[[File:Olympic rings without rims.svg|thumb|Olympic Logo]] This article considers social media coverage of the Olympics, and how it has evolved over the past decades. == Background == The Olympics is able to advertise to its viewers and its host country with the use of data it collects through [[Social_media_marketing|Social media marketing]]. Prominent [[List_of_social_networking_websites|social media platforms]] include: Twitter, Facebook, Instagram, Tumblr, YouTube, Google, MSN, Yahoo and many more. Campaign Initiatives and [[Artificial_intelligence|Artificial Intelligence]] technologies have been used to analyze the social media content of users. Information from consumers such as their preferences, demographics, age and locality are all analyzed to gain [[Customer_insight|consumer insight]]. Campaign initiatives and AI technologies were used for such purposes in the 2010 Vancouver Winter Olympics and are in use currently.<ref>{{cite web | first1=Caitlin | last1=Hamilton | url=https://www.wired.com/2010/02/olympic-marketing-matches-made-in-social-media-heaven/ | title=Olympic Marketing Matches Made in Social Media Heaven | accessdate=March 6, 2018 | website=[[Wired (magazine)|Wired (magazine)]] | date=February 24, 2010}}</ref> Social media marketing of the Olympics is a new phenomena, beginning prior to the 2008 Beijing Olympics <ref>{{cite web|last1=Liu|first1=Yinya|title=The Development of Social Media and its Impact on the Intercultural Exchange of the Olympic Movement|url=https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/09523367.2017.1285285?src=recsys#_i8|website=www.tandfonline.com|publisher=Taylor & Francis|accessdate=14 March 2018}}</ref>
== Variations == There are two classifications of social media marketing recognized by the [[International_Olympic_Committee|IOC]]:
* Officially sanctioned content from rights holders and sponsors that maximizes the use of Olympic content (imagery, [[Hashtag|hashtag]]) * Unofficial content that is generated by brands that leverage the excitement of the Olympics<ref>{{cite web | first1=Wally | last1=Peterson | url=http://sendible.com/insights/winning-olympics-social-media-campaigns | title=Medal Winning Social Media Campaigns from the Olympics | accessdate=March 6, 2018 | website=Sendible Insights | date=September 2, 2016}}</ref>
== 2008 Beijing Summer Olympics == Social media marketing emerged as a phenomenon during the 2008 Beijing Olympics, which progressed as a marketing and an advertising tactic ever since.<ref name=developt&f/> The Beijing Olympics became the test subject for social media marketing initiatives started by advertising agencies. In 2008, social media marketing began the transition from one-sided communication to [[Mass_communication|mass communication]] of the Olympic Games. Although social media marketing of the Olympic Games began in 2008, the audience to the Olympics was still primarily reached through television–reaching an audience of 4.3 billion viewers. At the time, the viewers of the Olympic Games through Internet website platforms made up an audience of approximately 390 million individuals.{{citation needed|date=April 2018}}
What was the beginning of Olympic social media marketing, was also the beginning of a more globalized experience of the Olympic Games via social media. Twitter, now a prominent social media platform, began in 2006 and grew to three million active users by the beginning of the 2008 Beijing Olympics. Members of Facebook, another prominent social media platform, tracking the Olympic Games grew from approximately one million during the Olympic Games of Athens 2004 to 90 million during the 2008 Beijing Olympics.<ref name=developt&f>{{cite journal|last1=Liu|first1=Yinya|title=The Development of Social Media and its Impact on the Intercultural Exchange of the Olympic Movement|doi=10.1080/09523367.2017.1285285|journal=The International Journal of the History of Sport|date=February 21, 2017}}</ref> Social media use, in general, increased by 24 percent between 2007 and 2008–from 63 percent of U.S. adults to 87 percent of U.S. adults.<ref>{{cite web | first1=Gigi | last1=Devault | url=https://www.thebalance.com/case-study-the-olympic-games-and-social-media-2296752 | title=Case Study - The Olympic Games and Social Media | accessdate=6 March 2018 | website=The Balance | date=October 27, 2016}}</ref>
== 2010 Vancouver Winter Olympics == The International Olympic Committee (IOC) deemed The [[2010_Winter_Olympics|Vancouver Winter Olympics]] as "the first social media games” based on its fan base through social media platforms.<ref name=vancouver2010first/> The IOC launched their [[Facebook]] page a month before the games began, attracting 1.5 million fans. Shifting to online viewing attracted a younger audience than past Olympic games with over 60 percent of Facebook fans being under 24 years of age.<ref name=vancouver2010first/>
[[File:Shaun White 27913015.jpg|thumb|Shaun White]]
Athletes like [[Lindsey Vonn]] and [[Shaun White]] reached fans on social media as the platform posted behind-the-scenes coverage on their experiences.<ref name="vancouver2010first">{{cite web | url=https://www.olympic.org/news/vancouver-2010-the-first-social-media-games | title=Vancouver 2010: The First Social Media Games | publisher=[[International Olympic Committee]] | accessdate=March 6, 2018 | date=March 22, 2010}}</ref> The IOC used social media to create competitions between athletes and fans streamed online. Its [[YouTube]] channel hosted a “Best of Us” challenge in which the public could compete in games with their favorite athletes, acquiring three million viewers.<ref name=vancouver2010first/> Photos spread across social media platforms, such as [[Flickr]], which had 11,000 photos posted by 600 photographers, bringing a new perspective to the games.<ref name=vancouver2010first/>
[[Twitter]] contributed constant live updates of the competitions. The IOC’s twitter following doubled to 12,000 followers during the Vancouver Olympics, creating a larger viewer population for the games.<ref name=vancouver2010first/> The IOC created social media guidelines as more athletes and fans got online to interact with the Olympics.<ref>{{cite web | first1=Mark | last1=Mcclusky | url=https://www.wired.com/2010/02/athletes-confused-on-olympic-social-media-rules/ | title=Athletes Confused by Olympic Social Media Rules | accessdate=March 6, 2018 | website=[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]] | date=February 5, 2010}}</ref> Social media was still relatively new as a marketing platform, so these guidelines confused many individuals.<ref>{{cite web | first1=Mark | last1=Mcclusky | url=https://www.wired.com/2010/02/athletes-confused-on-olympic-social-media-rules/ | title=Athletes Confused by Olympic Social Media Rules | accessdate=March 6, 2018 | website=[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]] | date=February 5, 2010}}</ref>
== 2012 London Summer Olympics == The London 2012 Olympic Games succeeded in [[broadcasting]], participation and marketing. For the first time, the IOC broadcast the Olympic Games live and on-demand through Youtube,<ref>{{cite web | url=http://view.digipage.net/go/ioclondon2012/#42 | title=IOC Marketing Report | publisher=[[International Olympic Committee]] | accessdate=March 6, 2018}}</ref> allowing fans to access the Games anytime, anywhere through [[Live_streaming|live streaming]].<ref name="Worldarchery">{{cite web | url=https://worldarchery.org/news/101308/london-2012-facts-and-figures) | title=London 2012 Facts and Figures | accessdate=March 6, 2018 | website=Worldarchery.com | date=November 23, 2012}}</ref> The combination of conventional broadcasting and [[Mobile_device|mobile platforms]] reached a global audience of 4.8 billion people.<ref name=Worldarchery/>
[[Social media]] soared with Facebook, Twitter and [[Google+]], attracting 4.7 million followers. Athletes shared photographs, interacted online with fans and updated daily, either in person or via an agent.<ref>{{cite news| first1=Eric | last1=Pfanner | url=http://link.galegroup.com/apps/doc/A295008425/AONE?u=ksstate_ukans&sid=AONE&xid=4eb2cc97 | title=Social Media's Role in London Games Grows With Surge in Users | accessdate=March 6, 2018 |date=July 2, 2012 |newspaper=[[The New York Times]]}}</ref> Instagram was established by 2012, making itself a premier photo-sharing platform perfect for athletes to capture their emotions.<ref name="howriochanged">{{cite web | first1=Gabriela | last1=Barkho | url=https://later.com/blog/how-social-media-changed-the-olympics-and-rio-2016/ | title=How Social Media Changed the Olympics, and What it Means for #Rio2016 | accessdate=March 6, 2018 | website=Later.com | date=August 11, 2016}}</ref> Lewis Wiltshire, head of sport for Twitter UK said, "Never before have fans had such direct access to their sporting heroes."<ref>{{cite web | url=http://view.digipage.net/go/ioclondon2012/#42 | title=IOC London 2012 Marketing Report | publisher=[[International Olympic Committee]] | accessdate=March 6, 2018}}</ref>
[[File:Usain BoltLondon2012.jpg|thumb|Usain BoltLondon2012]]
Social media created conversation on fan opinions regarding athletes, including 962,756 total mentions of [[Usain_Bolt|Usain Bolt]], “Fastest Man in History,” who defended the 100 meter and 200 meter gold medals. [[Michael Phelps]] followed with 828,081 total mentions.<ref>{{cite web | first1=Sam | last1=Laird | url=https://mashable.com/2012/08/14/2012-olympics-social-media-winners-infographic/#15TAq6uoHuqa | title=2012 Olympics: The Social Media Winners | accessdate=March 6, 2018 | website=[[Mashable]] | date=August 14, 2012}}</ref>
Olympic sponsors were active on social media; created several campaigns to promote their brands; and inspired viewers with mass participation and personalized events.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.nesta.org.uk/social-media-scale-and-london-2012 | title=Social Media at Scale and London 2012 | publisher=[[Nesta (charity)|Nesta]] | accessdate=March 6, 2018 | website=nesta.org.uk}}</ref> The [[Adidas]] “Take the Stage” Campaign recognized talent around the world, installing a [[Photo_booth|photo booth]] and inviting the 550 Olympics athletes to take the stage. (IOC Marketing Report 2012). [[David_Beckham|David Beckham]] surprised fans at the photo booth in Westfield shopping centre, gaining popularity in UK media. [[Coca-Cola]], [[Acer_Inc.|Acer Inc.]], [[McDonald's|McDonald’s]], [[Visa_Inc.|Visa Inc.]] and several others used similar tactics of participation to attract viewers.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://view.digipage.net/go/ioclondon2012/#42 | title=IOC Marketing Report | publisher=[[International Olympic Committee]] | accessdate=March 6, 2018}}</ref>
== 2014 Sochi Winter Olympics == === Channels ===
The [[2014 Winter Olympic Games]] were held in [[Sochi]], a city in [[Krasnodar Krai]], Russia, establishing the first “social media Olympics” for Russia. The most popular Russian social media and networking service, [[VKontakte|VK]], created an Olympic page, similar to Facebook’s. The Olympic VK page has 2.8 million fans and--the most popular official community on the platform.<ref name="sochicool">{{cite web | url=https://www.olympic.org/news/sochi-2014-social-media-metrics-hot-numbers-cool-conversations-all-yours | title=Sochi 2014 Social Media Metrics: Hot Numbers. Cool Conversations. All Yours. | publisher=[[International Olympic Committee]] | accessdate=March 6, 2018}}</ref> Throughout the games, VK had 54 million Olympic mentions, an average of 1.5 million per day.<ref name=sochicool/>
Numbers grew on other social media pages: more than 2 million fans joined the Olympic Facebook page, 168,101 followed the Olympic twitter, 150,000 followed the Olympic instagram and three million visited the Olympic website in February 2014.<ref name=sochicool/> There were 90,000 total updates on social media by Sochi 2014 Olympians and teams. The United States was the most active country during the games logging 22,598 posts across Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram.<ref name=sochicool/>
=== Engagement ===
With social media there is also hashtags. The most popular hashtag was #sochi2014 with almost 11,000 uses. The next top five hashtags were #wearewinter, #teamusa, #olympics, #goaus and #wirfuerD.<ref name="sochiportrayed">{{cite web | first1=Diana | last1=Petrescu | url=http://www.business-review.eu/featured/sochi-2014-how-the-winter-olympic-games-are-portrayed-in-social-media-55681 | title=Sochi 2014: How the Winter Olympic games are portrayed in social media | accessdate=March 6, 2018 | work=[[Business Review]] | date=February 11, 2014}}</ref> Another popular hashtag was #Sochiproblems, depicting local struggles. Photos of the poor state of Sochi on all platforms made the games the number one trending topic one week before the opening ceremony. #SochiFail and #SochiProblems gave multiple reports of the poor living arrangements, incomplete construction, broken elevators, and polluted waters. This was one way that social media provided awareness to its users.<ref name=sochiportrayed/>
=== Media Perceptions ===
Media perceptions varied during the games; the Olympics was viewed as a confrontation between Eastern and Western Civilizations. The [[LGBT]] community took a stand against the games. Sponsors for the games including Coca-Cola, Mcdonald’s, and [[Procter & Gamble|P&G]] protested against Russian authorities.<ref name=sochiportrayed/> Many protests took a stand against Russian laws, which created a discussion between human rights advocates. Advocates believed organizations should not promote certain values in western markets while supporting an anti-human rights government in another market.<ref name=sochiportrayed/>
== 2016 Rio Summer Olympics == [[File:Thomas Bach (13951010204).jpg|thumb|Thomas Bach]] Social media marketing was an influential tool in the promotion and analysis of the [[2016_Summer_Olympics|2016 Rio Olympics]]. [[Thomas_Bach|Thomas Bach]], President of the International Olympic Committee said that the power of sport demonstrates that diversity and [[Interconnectivity|interconnectedness]] can enlighten us all.<ref name="ioc-rio">{{cite web | url=http://touchline.digipage.net/iocmarketing/reportrio2016/32-1 | title=IOC Rio 2016 Marketing Report | publisher=[[International Olympic Committee]] | accessdate=March 6, 2018}}</ref> With over 25,000+ sources of accredited media covering the games, the 2016 games were the most consumed Olympic games to date.<ref name=ioc-rio/> Marketing for the Rio Olympics began in 2013 and ultimately lasted 3 years. There were 26 million visits to Olympic.org, the official website of the Olympic games, and over 7 billion views of official Olympic content on social media.<ref name=ioc-rio/> There were over 270 digital media platforms covering the games and active engagement throughout various social media platforms including facebook and twitter.<ref name=ioc-rio/>
Twitter saw over 187 million tweets inspired by the Rio Olympics, a 24.6 percent increase from the 2012 Summer Olympics.<ref name="how2016change">{{cite web | first1=Andrew | last1=Hutchinson | url=https://www.socialmediatoday.com/social-networks/how-2016-rio-olympics-dominated-social-media-infographic | title=How the 2016 Rio Olympics Dominated Social Media | accessdate=March 6, 2018 | work=Social Media Today | date=August 24, 2016}}</ref> The 187 million tweets generated nearly 75 billion twitter impressions.<ref name=how2016change/> It is important to note that throughout this same period, twitter nearly doubled in size in terms of users, suggesting that there could have been an even larger growth in twitter engagement. The hashtag, #Rio2016 was official content created by the IOC to generate buzz and encourage engagement.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Barkho|first1=Gabriella|title=How Social Media Changed the Olympics, and What it Means for #Rio2016|url=https://later.com/blog/how-social-media-changed-the-olympics-and-rio-2016/|website=Later|accessdate=27 March 2018}}</ref>
Facebook saw 277 million people interact 1.5 billion times regarding the 2016 games.<ref name=how2016change/> Comparatively to the London games, which saw 116 million posts, there was a significant increase in interaction. Facebook also used the Rio Olympics to debut their Sponsored Photo Frame aspect as an alternative method of advertising revenue and marketing outreach. The idea behind this innovation was to present a new advertising opportunity for the platform and to encourage alternative interaction in a similar way to which [[Snapchat]] uses paid and sponsored [[Timeline_of_Snapchat|geographic filters]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Barkho|first1=Gabriella|title=How Social Media Changed the Olympics, and What it Means for #Rio2016|url=https://later.com/blog/how-social-media-changed-the-olympics-and-rio-2016/|website=Later|accessdate=27 March 2018}}</ref>
The Rio Olympics was the first Olympics to utilize snapchat as a marketing tool.<ref name=howriochanged/> NBC directly partnered with Snapchat and [[BuzzFeed|Buzzfeed]] to promote the 2016 games.<ref name=howriochanged/>
== References == {{reflist}}
[[Category:Social media]] [[Category:Olympic culture]]

{{Infobox film | name = Too Colourful for the League | image = | director = [[Daniel Cross (filmmaker)|Daniel Cross]]
[[Mila Aung-Thwin]] | producer = Diversus Productions
[[Ari Cohen]], [[Evan Beloff]], [[Max Wallace]], [[Daniel Cross (filmmaker)|Daniel Cross]] | writer = [[Max Wallace]] | starring = | music = | editing = | released = 2001 | runtime = 52 minutes | country = Canada | language = English | budget = | website = }} '''''Too Colourful for the League''''' is a 52-minutes 2001 Canadian [[documentary film]] made for CBC-TV, directed by [[Daniel Cross (filmmaker)|Daniel Cross]] and [[Mila Aung-Thwin]] and produced by Diversus Productions. The film was produced by [[Evan Beloff]], [[Ari Cohen]] and [[Max Wallace]], who were nominated for a [[Gemini Award]] for best documentary. It was written by [[Max Wallace]] and co-produced by [[Daniel Cross (filmmaker)|Daniel Cross]]. This documentary examines the struggle of blacks in [[Ice hockey|hockey]] in [[Canada]] from the 1930s to the present day telling the story of black players' courage and determination to play in a white-dominated sport.{{cite web|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=8E74agb2dk4C&pg=PA173&lpg=PA173&dq=Too%20Colourful%20for%20the%20League&source=bl&ots=tEYQt8CJxh&sig=jZrnkAW-xuxFJxJZAB3ctuikISE&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjf57y-kcHTAhUhDcAKHdGnABg4ChDoAQgiMAA#v=onepage&q=Too%20Colourful%20for%20the%20League&f=false|title=Breaking the Ice: The Black Experience in Professional Hockey|first=Cecil|last=Harris|date=1 January 2007|publisher=Insomniac Press|accessdate=26 April 2017|via=Google Books}} It focuses on an effort by former Montreal citizenship judge Richard Lord to nominate legendary black hockey player [[Herb Carnegie]] into the [[Hockey Hall of Fame]]. During the 1940s, Carnegie was widely acknowledged as one of the best hockey players in the world, playing alongside [[Jean Béliveau]] for the Quebec Aces. Yet he never was allowed to play in the NHL because of a long-time color barrier, which was only broken a decade later by [[Willie O'Ree]] of the [[Boston Bruins]].{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/03/10/sports/hockey/herb-carnegie-dies-trailblazer-never-got-his-nhl-shot.html|title=A Hockey Trailblazer Who Missed His Chance|date=10 March 2012|work=The New York Times|accessdate=26 April 2017}} In the film, veteran [[Hockey Hall of Fame]] referee [[Red Storey]] recalls watching Carnegie try out for Toronto Maple Leafs owner [[Conn Smythe]]. According to Storey, Smythe turned to him and said, "I'd give $10,000 to turn that boy white." It was broadcast by [[CBC Television|CBC]], [[CTV television network|CTV]], [[CBC Newsworld]] and [[Canal Plus]]. ==See also== *[[List of black ice hockey players]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{IMDb title|0850717|Too Colourful for the League}} {{EyeSteelFilm}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Too Colourful For The League}} [[Category:2001 films]] [[Category:EyeSteelFilm films]] [[Category:Canadian films]] [[Category:Canadian documentary films]] [[Category:Documentary films about ice hockey]] [[Category:Black Canadian films]] [[Category:Documentary films about racism in Canada]] [[Category:History of Black people in Canada]] [[Category:2000s documentary films]] [[Category:Racism in sport]] [[Category:Anti-black racism in Canada]] [[Category:Films directed by Daniel Cross]] {{2000s-Canada-film-stub}} {{sport-documentary-film-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2012}} [[Image:StourbridgeFC.jpg|thumb|right|A football match in progress at the ground.]] The '''War Memorial Athletic Ground''', often referred to as simply the '''War Memorial Ground''', is a [[sports ground]] in the [[Amblecote]] region of [[Stourbridge]], [[West Midlands (county)|West Midlands]], [[England]]. It plays host to both [[cricket]] and [[football (soccer)|football]], being the home of [[Stourbridge Cricket Club]] and [[Stourbridge F.C.|Stourbridge Football Club]].
==Cricket==
===International=== Two [[ICC Trophy]] matches have been played at the War Memorial Ground: [[Bermudian cricket team|Bermuda]] v [[Papuan cricket team|Papua New Guinea]] in 1979, and [[Argentine cricket team|Argentina]] v [[East African cricket team|East Africa]] in 1986. The ground also hosted a match in the 1997 [[Triple Crown Tournament]], between an England Cricket Board XI <!--*not* England and Wales Cricket Board in this particular case--> and [[Irish cricket team|Ireland]].
===Domestic=== [[Worcestershire County Cricket Club]] played 61 [[first-class cricket|first-class]] matches at the ground: 60 between 1905 and 1962, and a further one in 1981. All these games were in the [[County Championship]]. Only three [[List A cricket|List A]] games have been played here, in 1969, 1970 and 1982, again all involving Worcestershire. The county played Second XI cricket at the ground into the early 1990s.
On this ground in 1911, Worcestershire lost to [[Lancashire County Cricket Club|Lancashire]] by 372 runs, which as of the beginning of the 2009 season remains the county's largest ever defeat in terms of runs. <ref>{{cite web | url=http://cricketarchive.co.uk/Archive/Records/England/Firstclass/Worcestershire/Team_Records/Largest_Defeat_by_Runs.html | title=Largest Margin of Runs Defeat | accessdate=6 January 2007 | publisher=CricketArchive}}</ref>
===Records===
====First-class==== * '''Highest team total:''' 592/9 declared by [[Lancashire County Cricket Club|Lancashire]] v Worcestershire, 1909 * '''Lowest team total:''' 43 by Worcestershire v [[Kent County Cricket Club|Kent]], 1913 * '''Highest individual innings:''' 217 by [[Frederick Bowley (Worcestershire cricketer)|Frederick Bowley]] for Worcestershire v [[Leicestershire County Cricket Club|Leicestershire]], 1905 * '''Best bowling in an innings:''' 9-40 by [[Reg Perks]] for Worcestershire v [[Glamorgan County Cricket Club|Glamorgan]], 1939
====List A==== * '''Highest team total:''' 164/9 (40 overs) by Worcestershire v Leicestershire, 1970<ref name="Seventy">Same match.</ref> * '''Lowest team total:''' 104 (37.5 overs) by Glamorgan v Worcestershire, 1969 * '''Highest individual innings:''' 58 by [[Nigel Briers]] for Leicestershire v Worcestershire, 1982 * '''Best bowling in an innings:''' 4-24 by [[Bob Carter (cricketer, born 1937)|Bob Carter]] for Worcestershire v Leicestershire, 1970<ref name="Seventy">Same match.</ref>
==Football==
The War Memorial Athletic Ground is also the home of [[Stourbridge F.C.]] The ground hosted League One team [[Walsall F.C.|Walsall]] in the FA Cup 1st round on 7 November 2009. The match finished in a 0-1 loss for Stourbridge.<ref>Ihttp://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/fa_cup/8341086.stm</ref> It also hosted a replay between Stourbridge and [[Plymouth Argyle]] in the [[2011–12 FA Cup|FA Cup]] on 22 November 2011.
==Notes== <references />
==References== * [http://cricketarchive.co.uk/Archive/Grounds/11/764.html Amblecote, Stourbridge] from CricketArchive. (This is the only name CA gives to the ground.) Retrieved 19 December 2006.
{{Worcestershire CCC}} {{Men's Football in the West Midlands}}
{{coord|52|27|45.20|N|2|09|04.89|W|type:landmark|display=title}}
[[Category:Football venues in the West Midlands (county)]] [[Category:Welsh Cup final venues]] [[Category:Cricket grounds in the West Midlands (county)]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1905]] [[Category:World War I memorials in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Stourbridge]]

{{Infobox website | name = WhatIfSports.com | favicon = | logo = WhatIfSports logo.png | screenshot = | caption = | url = [http://www.whatifsports.com www.whatifsports.com] | alexa = {{IncreaseNegative}} 24,720 ({{as of|2014|4|1|alt=April 2014}})<ref name="alexa">{{cite web|url= http://www.alexa.com/siteinfo/whatifsports.com |title= Whatifsports.com Site Info | publisher= [[Alexa Internet]] |accessdate= 2014-04-01 }}</ref><!--Updated monthly by OKBot.--> | commercial = Yes | type = Sports simulation | registration = Optional | owner = SportsHub Technologies | author = Tarek Kamil | launch date = 1999 | current status = Active | revenue = }} '''WhatIfSports.com''' is a company based in [[Cincinnati, Ohio]], U.S. that specializes in [[online]] [[sports]] [[simulations]] and [[fantasy sport|fantasy]]-style games. It uses custom sports simulators to allow users to match teams from any era and generate a complete [[play-by-play]] of a game. Simulations can be run for free, or users can build custom teams consisting of [[sportsperson|players]] from any generation and join leagues with their friends for a fee. Results are based on each player's combined stats from previous seasons.
The site won the 2005 [[Webby Awards|Webby]] award as the best sports website and claims more than 600,000 users as of 2009.{{Citation needed|date=June 2008}}
==Company history== Founded in 1999, WhatIfSports was a side project of a couple of sports fans working for a computer [[Information technology consulting|consulting]] company in Cincinnati, Ohio. After numerous lunchroom debates on which great historical [[baseball]] teams would win if they could play each other, a few guys decided to up the ante. At the height of the [[dot-com bubble]], they decided to undertake the challenge of trying to write an advanced baseball simulator (along the lines of [[Strat-O-Matic]] and [[APBA]]) that would work on a website.
An early version of the baseball simulator was up and running by fall of 1999. The next project was [[college basketball]]. Just in time for [[NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Championship|March Madness]] in spring of 2000, the college basketball simulator went online. This caught the attention of the local media when the simulator said the [[University of Cincinnati]] would have made the [[Final Four]] if one of its players, power forward [[Kenyon Martin]], had not broken his leg.
While continuing with the consulting work to pay the bills, WhatIfSports remained a side project until the company landed its first major license with Major League Baseball in 2001. The license put the baseball simulator on [[MLB.com]] and put WhatIfSports on the map.
In the years that followed, the WhatIfSports project began earning more money than the computer consulting work, as more and more companies began trimming back their [[information technology]] budgets. In 2003 WhatIfSports was officially [[incorporation (business)|incorporated]]; a growing staff was able to introduce new simulators for [[American football|football]], [[NBA]] basketball, [[ice hockey|hockey]], and [[stock car racing]].
After two more years of continuous growth, WhatIfSports was acquired by [[News Corporation|Fox Interactive Media]] in the fall of 2005. This was around the same time Fox bought other properties such as [[MySpace]], [[IGN]] and [[Scout.com]].
==Games==
===SimMatchup=== The sites SimMatchup feature lets users pit any two teams against each other. The list of [[MLB]] teams goes back to the 1885, [[NFL]] football teams back to 1941, [[NHL]] hockey teams back to 1917, NBA basketball teams back to 1950, and [[NCAA basketball]] teams goes back to different years depending on the team. All simulators produce complete [[box score]]s and full play-by-play.
===SimLeagues=== The sites SimLeagues lets users draft their own teams consisting of any player in [[MLB]], [[NBA]], [[NFL]] and [[NHL]] history and join [[sports league|leagues]] with other people. All leagues play full seasons (by today's standards) with playoffs. Complete stats are tracked for all players and teams.
===Dynasty games=== The site has dynasty games for college football, college basketball, soccer and baseball where the user manages a team of fictional players over the course of several seasons. The user controls roster management, game planning, and in the college dynasties can advance from Division III schools up to Division I schools. In those games they have real colleges, but not players. There are other people who are also in the world with you.<ref>http://www.whatifsports.com/soccer</ref>
==Forums and other features== The site offers extensive user [[web forum|forums]] for each of the major sports, along with more general discussions and a section called "The Pit" for trash talk and more mature themes. Generally, the most active forum is Baseball (Sim Baseball and Hardball Dynasty, along with MLB talk.) On August 14, 2007 a soccer forum was introduced to talk about all things soccer.
The site also offers a section called "Beyond the Box Score" which are a series of columns which contain weekly [[NFL]] projections on games and individual [[Fantasy football (American)|fantasy football]] performers, as well as explorations of various "what if" scenarios. In March 2008, the simulator correctly predicted seven of the eight elite 8 teams, all Final Four teams, the runner-up Memphis and champion Kansas.<ref>[http://www.whatifsports.com/beyondtheboxscore/default.asp?article=20080317 Beyond the Box Score: Bracket Previewed]</ref>
For a short period of time the site had a Legends Chat. Well-known coaches or athletes would receive questions from users. The questions were screened and had to be submitted the day before the chat. There were only seven of these chats: [[Davey Johnson]] (11/28/06), [[Dan Reeves]] (12/5/06), [[Bobby Cremins]] (12/19/06), [[Jack Lengyel]] (1/23/07), [[John Robinson (football coach)|John Robinson]] (2/1/07), [[John Chaney (basketball coach)|John Chaney]] (2/14/07) and [[Jud Heathcote]] (3/7/07).
==Controversy== Fox's acquisition of the site was controversial with some users. There was also a dispute involving [[copyright]] issues about Major League Baseball [[logo]]s and player names and likenesses. When a [http://www.dmwmedia.com/news/2006/08/10/judge-rules-against-mlb-says-fantasy-sports-data-is-public-domain lawsuit] was filed by CDM Fantasy Sports against the [[Major League Baseball Players Association]] and [[MLBAM|Major League Baseball Advanced Media]] (MLB's new media unit) over the use of such material, WhatIfSports eliminated MLB logos and player names and images, substituting generic descriptions of the players. This move generated some controversy with users, though the player names were restored after a federal court decision in favor of CDM Fantasy Sports. The logos have not yet been restored due to continuing copyright concerns.

|- align="center" bgcolor="#eeeeee" || '''Arena''' || |- align="center" || '''Club Colours''' || |} '''ZTR Zaporizhia''' is a [[team handball]] club from [[Zaporizhia]], [[Ukraine]]. Currently, ZTR Zaporizhia competes in the [[Ukrainian Men's Handball Super League]]. The club was before called '''ZYY''' and '''ZeMtY'''. The club is renamed ZTR Zaporizhia in 1992. ==The Club's history== Handball Club ZTR (before called '''ZYY''' and '''ZeMtY''') was established in 1966 on the basis of Zaporozhe branch of Dnepropetrovsk metallurgy institute. In 1992 Zaporozhye Transformer Plant ([[Zaporozhtransformator]]) has become a sponsor of the club, which was renamed to “ZTR”. ==Accomplishments== *'''[[EHF Cup]]:''' 1 **Winner: 1983 **Finalist: 1985 *'''[[Ukrainian Men's Handball Super League]]''' 14 **Champion: 1993, 1995, 1998, 1999, 2000, 2001, 2003, 2004, 2005, 2007, 2008, 2009, 2010, 2011 **Runner-up (9) : 1996, 1997, 2002, 2006, 2013, 2015, 2016, 2017, 2018 *'''[[Ukrainian Handball Cup]]:''' 2 **Winner: 2001, 2011 *'''[[Soviet Men's Handball Championship]]''' **Runner-up : 1971 == European record == {| class="wikitable" !
